top.byline: Dinah Voyles Pulver, Rachel Axon, Katie Wedell, Erin Mansfield, Zshekinah Collier, Tyreye Morris
top.title: January 6 Capitol Riot Arrests
top.headline: Capitol riot arrests: See who's been charged across the U.S.
top.intro:
Federal prosecutors have charged more than 800 people in 48 states with participating in the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, and arrests continue.

USA TODAY gathers details of those cases as the FBI continues to find and charge those responsible for the attack that left five people dead and sent lawmakers and Vice President Mike Pence fleeing to shelter.

Included are those arrested on charges federal prosecutors have filed since the riot, and those arrested by Capitol Police and D.C. Metro Police for entering the Capitol or for crimes related to weapons or violence. Check back for updates.

Support journalism like this with a subscription.
top.contributing: – Developed by the USA TODAY NETWORK Storytelling Studio

intro_image.caption: Rioting supporters of President Donald Trump climb the west wall of the the U.S. Capitol in Washington.
intro_image.alt: People climb the west wall of the the U.S. Capitol.

top.description: See who has been arrested in the Capitol riots. USA TODAY is gathering the latest as prosecutors continue to issue charges.

characters.name: Henry "Enrique" Tarrio
characters.title: Enrique
characters.charge: Seditious conspiracy; conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties; conspiracy to obstruct official proceeding; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder and aiding and abetting; destruction of government property and aiding and abetting (two counts); assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers (two counts)
characters.description:
Tarrio was charged with conspiracy related to the Capitol riot but was not at the Capitol that day. He was the national chairman of the Proud Boys on Jan. 6, 2021 and had been posting comments about the election and potential violence for weeks. For example, on Nov. 16, he posted: "If Biden steals this election, (the Proud Boys) will be political prisoners. We won't go quietly...I promise." He shared a Biden post about the virus on Nov. 25, saying "No, YOU need to remember the American people are at war with YOU. No Trump...No peace. No quarter." By late December, Tarrio and others had organized a new national chapter of the Proud Boys called the Ministry of Self Defense, with members to be "hand selected," according to court documents.

The Justice Department alleges Tarrio and others raised money to buy equipment and support travel for the Stop the Steal protest, obtained paramilitary gear, including concealed tactical vests and protective equipment and engaged in messaging and other planning before the protest. Court records also reference a document called "1776 returns," which laid out plans to "occupy" a few buildings in D.C. including the House and Senate office buildings with "as many people as possible." By early January, the membership of the "ministry" included 65 members, records show.

Tarrio was arrested in D.C. on Jan. 4, related to charges involving burning a "Black Lives Matter" banner at a church in December. His arrest prompted a flurry of activity in the group's messaging activities, with other leaders "nuking" one chat, telling people how to delete all messages, then setting up a new chat, voicing concern that their chat had been compromised. After Tarrio's release on Jan. 5, he met with Stewart Rhodes, founder and leader of the Oath Keepers, in a D.C. parking garage. Court records state Tarrio then traveled to Maryland, while other leaders in the national chapter carried out the leadership's objectives.

blurbs.text: Seditious conspiracy; conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties; conspiracy to obstruct official proceeding; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder and aiding and abetting; destruction of government property and aiding and abetting (two counts); assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers (two counts)

characters.name: Elmer Stewart Rhodes
characters.title: Stewart
characters.charge: Seditious conspiracy; conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties; tampering with documents or proceedings
characters.description: Stewart Rhodes is the founder and leader of the Oath Keepers, a paramilitary group that recruits former members of the military and police. Rhodes is charged with 10 others with conspiring to overturn the election of Joe Biden as president. Shortly after the election in November 2020, prosecutors say, Rhodes and others began planning travel to Washington D.C. and training for action there. As the crowd gathered outside the Capitol about 2 p.m. on Jan. 6, federal prosecutors say Rhodes entered the restricted area of the Capitol grounds and directed his followers to meet him at the Capitol. Court records say two groups of Oath Keepers, many in paramilitary clothing bearing Oath Keepers patches and insignia, then formed military-style "stack" formations and invaded the Capitol.

blurbs.text: Seditious conspiracy; conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties; tampering with documents or proceedings

characters.name: Ian Ross Horvath
characters.charge: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds.
characters.description: Horvath called the FBI on Sept. 14, 2021 to report his photos were on the bureau's most-wanted page for Capitol rioters. He told the FBI he drove to Washington D.C. on Jan. 5, 2021 with an acquaintance and slept in a truck overnight in a parking lot south of the White House. Wearing a coonskin cap, he walked with a group to the Capitol after the rally, and walked up the stairs near the scaffolding built for the inauguration and entered the building. Documents show he entered the Capitol at 2:18 and left at 2:50 p.m.

blurbs.text: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds.

characters.name: Shawndale Chilcoat
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in the gallery of Congress; disorderly conduct on the Capitol grounds; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings; obstruction or impeding any official proceeding.
characters.description:
The FBI began investigating Shawndale and Donald Chilcoat, who are married, when a tipster sent agents a screenshot of one of Shawndale’s Facebook posts: "OK so antifa is being blamed for breaking windows and storming congress. Um no, it was us I was with them and couldn't be more proud. Please stop giving them credit and realize trump's side has crazies too and they should stew on that for awhile." Another post stated: “This should be a warning to congress, just try it on the 20th and u wont have to worry about bidens day not having anyone show up!”

The pair entered the Capitol through a fire door on the northwest side of the Capitol, according to court records.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in the gallery of Congress; disorderly conduct on the Capitol grounds; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings; obstruction or impeding any official proceeding.

characters.name: Donald Chilcoat
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in the gallery of Congress; disorderly conduct on the Capitol grounds; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings; obstruction or impeding any official proceeding.
characters.description: The investigation into Donald Chilcoat and his wife, Shawndale, began shortly after the riot in January 2021. A tipster provided a screenshot of one of Shawndale's Facebook posts: "OK so antifa is being blamed for breaking windows and storming congress. Um no, it was us I was with them and couldn't be more proud. Please stop giving them credit and realize trumps side has crazies too and they should stew on that for awhile." Another post stated: “This should be a warning to congress, just try it on the 20th and u wont have to worry about bidens day not having anyone show up!”

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in the gallery of Congress; disorderly conduct on the Capitol grounds; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings; obstruction or impeding any official proceeding.

characters.name: Antonio Lamotta
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Lamotta was part of a group of rioters that pushed past police officers and entered the east wing of the rotunda on Jan. 6, court documents state. However, authorities were able to push Lamotta and other accused rioters out of the building roughly 8 minutes later, officials said. Antonio was identified in security footage by an agent who had interviewed him in Philadelphia 2 days after the presidential election in November, when he was arrested for carrying a firearm without a license.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Landon Manwaring
characters.charge: Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Court records show Manwaring has a plea agreement hearing for a single charge and an initial appearance set for August 26, 2022. No other information was available.

blurbs.text: Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Kasey Von Owen Hopkins
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

image.alt: Photo of Kasey Von Owen Hopkins

characters.description: The FBI identified Hopkins through his telephone number, detected inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6 for about 18 minutes, according to court records. After interviewing Hopkins at his home on Sept. 14, 2021, agents found Hopkins on video footage inside the Capitol, where he took a selfie with a bust of Winston Churchill and entered the office of Senator Jeffrey Merkley.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Derek Sulenta
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: A relative of Sulenta provided the FBI with his identity and photos from his Facebook page detailing his travel to Washington D.C. and inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. Among the posts revealed during a court-authorized search of his Facebook, the FBI found this post from Dec. 23, 2020: “I’ll be there Jan 6th to support the president no matter what happens” and “That’s the day he called for patriots to show up.” Posts on the 6th stated: “Dude we breached the capital (sic) building” and "Inside the capital(sic) building. This is wild!" The FBI stated Sulenta was inside the Capitol for about 47 minutes.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: James Robinson
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: In an interview with an FBI agent, Robinson said he went with a group of people to D.C. for the Jan. 6 rally, then got separated from them and "sucked into a large group of people" trying to gain access to the Capitol. He told the agent he understood he was not supposed to go into the Capitol but felt that because of his martial arts training he could help people he heard crying out.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jerod Thomas Bargar
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; unlawful possession of a firearm on Capitol grounds or buildings; unlawful possession of a pistol, firearm or ammunition outsider their home or place of business without a valid license; unlawful possession, sale or transfer any large capacity ammunition feeding device in the District of Columbia.
characters.description: Bargar carried a concealed pistol onto Capitol grounds and then lost it, where it was recovered by police officers on scene. By tracking the pistol through the pawn shop where it was purchased, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives was able to confirm the 9-millimeter semi-automatic belonged to him, according to court documents. A cartridge was in the chamber and the magazine held another 15 cartridges. Court documents state he told authorities he did not know at the time that it was illegal to possess a handgun in D.C. or on federal property. Bargar posted a photo of himself among the crowds that day on social media with the hashtags #FightForTrump, "#partiallypeacefulprotest #beapartof history.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; unlawful possession of a firearm on Capitol grounds or buildings; unlawful possession of a pistol, firearm or ammunition outsider their home or place of business without a valid license; unlawful possession, sale or transfer any large capacity ammunition feeding device in the District of Columbia.

characters.name: William Stephon Kit
characters.title: Semore Views
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: More than 11 months after the riot, a tipster provided the FBI with a collage of photos of Kit on the grounds and inside the Capitol, reporting he identified himself on the internet as Semore Views, a pro-Trump YouTuber. Later a tipster provided a YouTube video, where Kit appeared to be yelling at police on the upper west terrace and inside the building, according to court documents. He yelled: "My problem is with the politicians in the building right here." The documents state he was in the building for about four minutes.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Samuel Fontanez Rodriguez
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Rodriguez left a recorded phone message for the FBI Jan. 22, 2021 acknowledging that he entered the Capitol during the Jan. 6 riot. A subsequent interview with Rodriguez, photos, phone records and an interview with another arrestee, Jackson Kostolksy, confirmed that Rodriguez had taken part, court records say.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Dova Alina Winegeart
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in any restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildings; destruction of government property.
characters.description: Winegeart appears in a photo swinging a spiked pole at the glass window of a door to the Capitol and on surveillance video striking the window with the pole, the Department of Justice said in court documents. Cracks and holes in that window would cost more than $1,000 to repair, according to the Capitol architect. A witness who knows Winegeart told federal agents that she texted: “It’s our building. Not the governments. We are their bosses but get treated like dogs. I’m done with this government. It’s fight time non stop now. They asked for it.”

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in any restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildings; destruction of government property.

characters.name: William Hendry Mellors
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: The FBI identified a photo that appeared to show Mellors, wearing a blue hooded sweatshirt and a black hat with a Gadsden Flag patch, spraying police officers with a chemical on Jan. 6. The can he held matched a commercially available bear spray, agents said in court documents. Mellors admitted to the FBI in May 2022 that he brought two cannisters of bear spray to the Capitol.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: John Thomas Gordon
characters.charge: Civil disorder; destruction of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: FBI agents describe internet videos that show a man with Gordon’s distinctive head tattoos repeatedly throwing an object at the north door of the Capitol on Jan. 6. The door is surrounded by a fog of tear gas while police officers stand on the other side of a glass window.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; destruction of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Tyler Earl Ethridge
characters.charge: Civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
Ethridge participated in the initial breach of the Capitol's perimeter fencing, the FBI charges. After passing the barricades to the West Plaza, documents state he was pepper-sprayed and shot with rubber bullets as officers tried to disperse the crowd. He entered the Capitol from the west terrace door and spent about 30 minutes inside the building.

Ethridge posted several videos from the Capitol, including one where he stated: “I’m probably going to lose my job as a pastor after this … I think we’re to a point where talk is cheap. If this makes me lose my, my reputation, I don’t care.” In a comment on one of his posts, Ethridge wrote: "It truly felt like a peaceful revolution."

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Lilith Anton Saer
characters.title: "Drakken"
characters.charge: Entering and remaining with intent to impede or disrupt an official proceeding in a restricted building; disorderly or disruptive conduct in the Capitol buildings or grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: After several tipsters identified Saer as the blue-haired woman in a photograph inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, the FBI determined that she was a QAnon supporter also seen in inside the Capitol Jan. 6 on a livestream video and on closed-circuit security footage.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining with intent to impede or disrupt an official proceeding in a restricted building; disorderly or disruptive conduct in the Capitol buildings or grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Eric Cramer
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Two days after the riot, the FBI received an anonymous tip that Cramer’s daughter had posted on social media saying her father had participated. In a voluntary interview on Jan. 19, 2021, Cramer told a law enforcement officer that he and his brother, Country, drove to D.C. to see the election-related events on Jan. 6. Cramer said an officer hit him in the side with a baton while he was standing in a crowd between the reflecting pool and the scaffolding at the Capitol. He told authorities the officer dropped the baton and he picked it up, but the FBI said video from the scene showed Cramer grabbed the baton to prevent the officer from using it. Charging documents show the Cramer brothers entered the Capitol and spent about 5 minutes there.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Country Cramer
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Cramer originally denied entering the Capitol but later recanted his story, according to court records. He and his brother, Eric Cramer, drove to D.C. to see the election-related events, then entered the Capitol and spent about 5 minutes inside the building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Luke Michael Lints
characters.charge: Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: The FBI identified Lints on video repeatedly assaulting police in the Capitol’s lower west terrace tunnel on Jan. 6, 2021. Lints appears on video holding a police shield and pushing back against police officers, according to court documents, and he uses the riot shield to prevent an officer from closing a door to protect himself from the rioters.

blurbs.text: Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Bernard Joseph Sirr
characters.charge: Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; and an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: Sirr, who the Providence Journal reported works as a nuclear facilities engineer at Rhode Island’s only nuclear reactor, appears in videos repeatedly assaulting police, according to charging documents. He's shown in videos pushing against police shields as the crowded chants and resists officers on the west terrace. Eventually, the officers pushed the rioters out of the tunnel. The FBI confirmed that Sirr was on leave from his employer during the riot.

blurbs.text: Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; and an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Paul Edward Kovacik
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI identified Kovacik through its search of phone numbers detected in the Capitol that day. Kovacik admitted that he entered the Capitol on the west side and took an elevator to a higher floor, the FBI said. Although he estimated that he was in the building for 60 to 90 minutes, the FBI concluded he was in the building for about 25 minutes.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Michael Greene
characters.title: Michael Simmons or "Whiplash"
characters.charge: Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; obstruction of an official proceeding; conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; tampering with documents or proceedings.
characters.description: Greene is a member of the Oath Keepers. Prosecutors added him to a superseding indictment for other members of the far-right group in June 2022. Charging documents state he participated in online meetings ahead of the Capitol riot and Oath Keepers leader Stewart Rhodes named him as operations leader on Jan. 6. At 1:42 pm that day, Greene texted an acquaintance saying he was "storming the Capitol." At 3:09 p.m. he sent a text saying, "Congress evacuated." Authorities stated that at some point after Jan. 6, he deleted items from his cell phone that showed his involvement that day.

blurbs.text: Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; obstruction of an official proceeding; conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; tampering with documents or proceedings.

characters.name: Hatchet Speed
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
Speed is a petty officer first class in the U.S. Naval Reserves, who has been a software developer for a defense contractor. The FBI identified his presence at the Capitol through a list of unauthorized cell phone numbers detected in the building that day. Speed admitted to an undercover FBI employee that he went into the Capitol on Jan. 6 and made it into the Rotunda, according to charging documents. Of the plan to go to the Capitol, Speed told the employee that he and others planned to listen to the president's speech then go to the Capitol to protest the certification. In a later meeting, he told the undercover employee that he went with friends who were Proud Boys, and blamed "Antifa" for the broken windows. After learning of Vice President Mike Pence's actions, Speed told the employee the crowd "went in and we took control," and he called their actions "impressive."

"It should have gotten to the point where Nancy Pelosi should have resigned out of fear for her life. That's what should have happened," Speed told the employee, according to court records. In addition to discussing killing Jewish people to "wipe out the opposition" and using violence against members of the Anti-Defamation League, records stated Speed praised the writings of the 1996 Centennial Olympic Park bomber and the Unabomber, saying he was studying their writings to learn from them and "come up with a better game plan." The Associated Press reported his birth name was Daniel Abraham Speed.

Prosecutors said Speed went on a buying spree in the months after the riot and spent $50,000 on at least a dozen guns and other items at firearms retailers. During a search of his house, vehicles and storage unit, federal agents seized eight firearms and seven noise suppressors, but did not seize five additional firearms, because they determined those were outside the terms of the search warrant. Additionally they found 25 other firearms belonging to his housemates. In one court filing, the government wrote: "as someone entrusted by our government with a TS//SCO security clearance, Speed should have known better than to engage in his conduct on January 6."

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Todd Tilley
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Tilley entered the Capitol through the Senate wing doors, based on court records. In videos taken that day, he can be seen inside the Capitol for about 30 minutes, at one point chanting "stop the steal," the documents stated. Later that day, he texted his brother saying "Pence screwed us over."

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Frank Joseph Bratjan Jr.
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

image.alt: Photo of Frank Joseph Bratjan Jr.

characters.description: A year passed after the riot before the FBI received the tip that led them to Bratjan, a U.S. postal worker. The tipster was aware of a selfie Bratjan took in the Capitol and sent to his mother. The tipster told the FBI that Bratjan had been living in Syracuse, New York, but moved to his mother's home in Minnesota after becoming worried about investigations of rioters, according to charging documents. After identifying Bratjan, the FBI went through previous tips and found three earlier tips about his posts on Facebook and Instagram. However, about a week after the riot, he had deleted all his social accounts. On surveillance video, Bratjan can be seen among a crowd pushing against officers protecting the offices of Senator Mitch McConnell.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Luis Hallon
characters.charge: Remaining in a restricted building with intent to impede or disrupt official functions; disorderly or disruptive conduct on the Capitol grounds; parading in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Hallon traveled to D.C. from St. Cloud, Florida, with his wife, Traci Isaacs, and their friend Leslie Gray, who had applied to volunteer with the Oath Keepers. Court documents state Isaacs and Hallon remained in the Capitol for about 14 minutes after entering through the rotunda doors at about 3:02 p.m. Hallon told FBI agents he and his wife never intended to harm anyone or take over the Capitol, only to "peacefully exercise their rights."

blurbs.text: Remaining in a restricted building with intent to impede or disrupt official functions; disorderly or disruptive conduct on the Capitol grounds; parading in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Traci Isaacs
characters.charge: Remaining in a restricted building with intent to impede or disrupt official functions; disorderly or disruptive conduct on the Capitol grounds; parading in a Capitol building; impair a record or document for use in an official proceeding.
characters.description:
Isaacs traveled to D.C. from St. Cloud, Florida, with her husband, Luis Hallon, and her friend Leslie Gray. Isaacs, who had been a member of the Oath Keepers on and off since 2016, had recently applied to volunteer with the Oath Keepers. Court documents state Isaacs and Hallon were in the Capitol for about 14 minutes after entering through the rotunda doors at about 3:02 p.m. Her nephew William Isaacs was previously indicted on related charges, including conspiracy. The FBI recovered messages in the days after the riot showing she and her nephew discussed their activities on Jan. 6, including him asking her, "Do I work on scrubbing evidence or do I do school?"

She also texted another individual and said: "We are all Oathkeepers so they're going to (expletive) with us probably." In another message, sent on Jan. 7, 2021, she said: "It was (expletive) glorious. Tear gas shucked." Then on Jan. 12, she texted Gray: "Girl I almost had a heart attack last night. FBI keep putting up more pictures and for a second, I thought one was me. It's not me but holy (expletive) did I get instantly sick."

blurbs.text: Remaining in a restricted building with intent to impede or disrupt official functions; disorderly or disruptive conduct on the Capitol grounds; parading in a Capitol building; impair a record or document for use in an official proceeding.

characters.name: Leslie Gray
characters.charge: Remaining in a restricted building with intent to impede or disrupt official functions; disorderly or disruptive conduct on the Capitol grounds; obstruct, impede or interfere with a law enforcement officer; obstruction of an official proceeding.
characters.description: Gray traveled to D.C. from St. Cloud, Florida, with friends Luis Hallon and his wife, Traci Isaacs. Gray took videos inside the Capitol and stated, "I am in Congress. This is our house. ...I don't know what we are doing now but we are in here. We've taken it." Court documents state during the 16 minutes she was in the building, she repeatedly yelled "traitor" at law enforcement officers and pushed past an officer who told her not to proceed farther. The FBI stated she is repeatedly heard on video yelling "USA" and "Stop the steal!" Documents state she also recorded video of law enforcement officers. In one video, she turned the camera on herself and stated: "American patriots stormed the Capitol today. I am an American patriot. I stormed the Capitol today.”

blurbs.text: Remaining in a restricted building with intent to impede or disrupt official functions; disorderly or disruptive conduct on the Capitol grounds; obstruct, impede or interfere with a law enforcement officer; obstruction of an official proceeding.

characters.name: Dylan Rhylei Cronin
characters.charge: Destruction of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Dylan Cronin and his father, Kevin, and brother Kevin II appear in images on the Capitol's upper west terrace at 2:10 p.m. on Jan 6, according to charging documents. Dylan is seen kicking the exterior Senate Wing door, the documents say. Other videos showed Dylan breaking a window and entering the Capitol and show the three men inside the building. Dylan Cronin served in the National Guard in Washington state.

blurbs.text: Destruction of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Kevin Cronin II
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Kevin Cronin II, his father, Kevin, and brother Dylan, appear in images on the Capitol's upper west terrace at 2:10 p.m. on Jan. 6. and images show Dylan kicking the exterior Senate Wing door, according to charging documents. Other videos showed Dylan breaking a window and entering the Capitol and show the three men inside the building. Kevin had been serving in the U.S. Army Reserve.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Kevin Cronin
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Kevin Cronin, a postal service employee, and his two sons, Dylan and Kevin II, appear in images on the Capitol's upper west terrace at 2:10 p.m. on Jan 6, and images show Dylan kicking the exterior Senate Wing door, according to charging documents. Other videos showed Dylan breaking a window and entering the Capitol, and the three men inside the building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Ryan Kelley
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; knowingly engage in any act of physical violence against a person or property in any restricted building or grounds; wilfully injure or commit any depredation against any property of the United States.
characters.description:
Kelley is a Republican candidate for governor in Michigan, and was a member of the planning commission in Allendale, Michigan. At the Capitol, he wore aviator sunglasses and a backwards black baseball cap, and was seen in the Capitol's Northwest Courtyard at about 3:26 p.m., after Capitol Police had started to regain control of parts of the building, according to charging documents. The documents compare his clothing to similar clothing Kelley wore at two American Patriot Council events in 2020. Earlier on Jan. 6, he was also seen climbing on scaffolding, directing others where to go and helping another rioter climb the scaffolding, according to the court documents. Kelley was a speaker at a "Stop the Steal" rally in Lansing, Michigan in November 2020, where he stated, "We're not going to let the Democrats steal this election."

In Kelley's case, multiple tips were provided to the FBI by online sleuths reviewing photos and videos, the agency stated.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; knowingly engage in any act of physical violence against a person or property in any restricted building or grounds; wilfully injure or commit any depredation against any property of the United States.

characters.name: David Walls-Kaufman
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI identified Walls-Kaufman after the widow of Capitol Police officer Jeffrey Smith named him in a lawsuit. Smith took his own life eight days after suffering brain injuries during the riot. The lawsuit and the FBI cited the work of the "Sedition Hunters," sleuths who have worked to track down Capitol rioters. The lawsuit included a photo of Walls-Kaufmann that stated it was taken at the Speaker's lobby entrance while Ashli Babbitt was lying on the floor after being shot. The FBI stated videos taken that day show Walls enter the Capitol through a doorway near an interior door to the rotunda and wander through the rotunda, statuary hall, east stairs and the upper house door. Charging documents indicate he was identified on the body cameras of 20 different Metropolitan Police Department officers.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Adam Lejay Jackson
characters.charge: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description:
Jackson and his brother, Brian, were charged after a witness told the FBI they participated in the Capitol riots and posted about it on Facebook. The brothers and a friend flew from Houston to Baltimore/Washington International Airport on Jan. 5 and returned on Jan. 7. After matching the men to their Facebook photos, agents determined the men were seen in video outside the tunnel in the lower west terrace assaulting a line of police officers around 5 p.m. Court records state Jackson is seen in videos wearing an American flag cape and attacking police officers, first by throwing a large object at Capitol Police and then by charging at them with a purloined riot shield.

In a set of messages on Jan. 10, Jackson admitted that he and his brother had been a part of the riot. The friend messaged, "Looks like you guys were all up in it!" Jackson replied, "We were. I'm (expletive) pissed at what is happening." Unlike his brother, who told a friend he would never go back to D.C., Jackson told his friend he wanted to go back for the inauguration. When the friend asked if the brothers brought the riot shield home, he replied: "No, we left them. Cost to(sic) much to ship home lol." Days later, he forwarded a message to friends and his brother that stated, "If POTUS doesn't stop this, he will be hunted down and arrested along with his entire family by the left. That's a fact. And with him gone, our country is gone too." The message concluded: "So yes, we are in a full blown Military Operation right now to remove the threats and install our President back in power and control the violence in the big cities."

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Brian Scott Jackson
characters.title: "Skooter"
characters.charge: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description:
Jackson and his brother, Adam, were charged after a witness told the FBI they participated in the Capitol riots and posted about it on Facebook. The brothers and a friend flew from Houston to Baltimore/Washington International Airport on Jan. 5 and returned on Jan. 7. After matching the men to their Facebook photos, agents determined the men were seen in video outside the tunnel in the lower west terrace assaulting a line of police officers around 5 p.m. and passing around a bottle of liquor. Court records state Jackson, wearing a red Trump hat, hurled a pole with an American flag on it at officers.

Jackson sent multiple messages asking people to delete videos and messages he had sent them and deleted one of his Facebook accounts, according to court records. In one set of messages, he used an offensive slur for Black people at least twice, referring to residents of the District of Columbia, and said he would never go back.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: James Brett IV
characters.charge: Civil disorder; obstruct, impede and interfere with law enforcement officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: Brett was named in a 2022 indictment with four other Florida men, three of whom had previously been arrested in the Capitol riot case and had been identified as members of the Proud Boys, Dion Rajewski, Alan Fischer III and Zachary Johnson. The Department of Justice said the men were part of a group involved in the violent conflict on the Lower West Terrace where law enforcement officers were trying to keep rioters from entering the building.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; obstruct, impede and interfere with law enforcement officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Brian Boele
characters.charge: Civil disorder; obstruct, impede and interfere with law enforcement officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: Boele was named in a 2022 indictment with four other Florida men, three of whom had previously been arrested in the Capitol riot case and had been identified as members of the Proud Boys, Dion Rajewski, Alan Fischer III and Zachary Johnson. The Department of Justice said the men were part of a group involved in the violent conflict on the Lower West Terrace where law enforcement officers were trying to keep rioters from entering the building.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; obstruct, impede and interfere with law enforcement officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Kimberly DiFrancesco
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI found DiFrancesco and her sister Trudy Castle after a tip that DiFrancesco had shared images taken inside the Capitol. Agents matched her identity to a phone number provided by the tipster. Court documents state they were outside the Senate Wing Door five minutes after the first rioters breached a window there. Castle was wearing a knitted winter "Trump" hat. Security footage showed they were in the building for about 36 minutes. At one point, it appeared DiFrancesco was talking on a handheld radio, an FBI agent wrote in the court documents. More than an hour later, the women were seen walking back toward the door in what appeared to be an unsuccessful effort to reenter the building.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty August 17, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty August 17, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Trudy Castle
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI found Castle and her sister Kimberly DiFrancesco after a tip that DiFrancesco had shared images taken inside the Capitol. Agents matched her identity to a phone number provided by the tipster. Court documents state they were outside the Senate Wing Door five minutes after the first rioters breached a window there. Castle was wearing a knitted winter "Trump" hat. Security footage showed they were in the building for about 36 minutes. They lingered outside the building for more than an hour, meeting up with a man the FBI identified as Castle's son, Nicholas Von Keudell. At 4:21 p.m., the women walked back toward the door and appeared to be a part of an effort to reenter the building, court documents stated.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty August 17, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty August 17, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Josiah Pablo Hueso
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Hueso flew Delta Airlines from Los Angeles to Washington D.C. on Jan. 5 and then back to Los Angeles on Jan. 7, the same day a long-time acquaintance tipped the FBI that Hueso was bragging about participating in the riot on Jan. 6. The FBI cited a You Tube video that identified Hueso by his first name, as he said: "a huge group of us stormed inside and as we started - we were basically shouting at the cops." Court documents show Hueso entering the Capitol on the Senate side of the building. When the FBI interviewed Hueso on July 9, 2021, he told agents he saw a man grab a crowbar, break a window on a side door and reach in to open the door and let people in.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Thaddis Derone Johnson Jr.
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Although Johnson initially told FBI agents during an interview that he did not enter the Capitol building, a source later provided video that showed otherwise, the FBI reported. Johnson, wearing a "Keep America Great" ball cap, is seen on video going in and out of the building before reentering and going to the Senate Parliamentarian's office. After about a minute, he went into another office where he also spent about a minute before leaving the building. In a second interview, court documents show, Johnson admitted to the FBI that he entered the building twice.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty August 10, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty August 10, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Adam Miller
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Miller and his brother-in-law, Devin Steiner, were reportedly in the Capitol building for about 35 minutes, according to court documents. A relative told the FBI that Miller was a follower of QAnon, according to reporting by the Akron Beacon Journal.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Devin Steiner
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building; disrupt the orderly conduct of official business.
characters.description: The Department of Justice charged Steiner and his brother-in-law, Adam Miller, after an investigation that started with an anonymous tip to the FBI. Steiner wore a camouflage jacket and a red, white and blue winter hat with the word Trump on it during the riot. Court documents state the men entered the building at about the same time members of Congress and Vice President Pence evacuated from the Chambers, according to the Akron Beacon Journal. The documents state Steiner and Miller remained in the building for about 35 minutes. The FBI reported finding a message in Steiner's phone that stated, "Storming the capitol building with hundreds of thousands!"

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building; disrupt the orderly conduct of official business.

characters.name: Levi Gable
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Gable posted about his experiences on Facebook, which an acquaintance promptly forwarded to the FBI. Gable's post stated he was among the first to make it inside the Capitol. "Capitol Police backed away from their stations and allowed protestors to make our way to the building," Gable wrote in the post. They wanted to protest Vice President Pence's statement that he would not challenge the results of the 2020 election, he said. Although his comments said the protest was peaceful, his video showed people yelling and chanting, court records show. During an interview with Gable on Jan. 21, 2021, the FBI said he repeatedly denied entering the building. However, the FBI found multiple photos of Gable in surveillance footage.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Bradley Bokoski
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Bradley Bokoski and his son Matthew were inside the Capitol for 4-5 minutes, according to court documents. Surveillance footage showed them entering and leaving through the Senate Parliamentarian door.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Matthew Bokoski
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Bradley Bokoski and his son Matthew, wearing a Trump stocking cap and a flag draped around his shoulders like a cape, were inside the Capitol for 4-5 minutes, according to court documents. Surveillance footage showed them entering and leaving through the Senate Parliamentarian door. Matthew Bokoski had posted comments and photos about his experience on Facebook, which a tipster turned over to the FBI. The FBI interviewed him in Chicago.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Karegan Bostic
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: While investigating the cases of Willard Thomas Bostic Jr. and his daughter Meghan Rutledge, the FBI concluded another daughter, Karegan Bostic, was with her father and sister that day, based on surveillance video and photos found on Rutledge's Facebook account.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Paula Ann Conlon
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Conlon is mentioned with Stacy Lee Bond in an information document prepared by the Department of Justice. Through a search of her Facebook account, the FBI agents said they found "a significant amount of content and communications regarding the belief that the 2020 Presidential election had been stolen or fraudulent," and stated the Jan. 6 rally should be "epic." Court records show she is seen in multiple images at the Capitol, and one video recorded her telling law enforcement officers to "back off."

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Stacy Lee Bond
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Bond is mentioned with Paula Ann Conlon in an information document prepared by the Department of Justice. Court documents state the FBI determined his phone had been used at the Capitol on Jan. 6. After identifying him, FBI agents concluded he was seen in numerous video clips from body worn camera footage. They also spoke with witnesses and in a Facebook search warrant found the following message he texted a friend: “I got there right after they broke in, I was pretty pissed, but I went in there just to go in and out the front door and got maced.”

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: George Amos Tenney III
characters.charge: Interfering with law enforcement officers during civil disorder; obstruction of Justice/Congress; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

image.alt: Photo of George Amos Tenney III

characters.description:
Tenney told authorities he is the administrator for a Facebook page called "The PowerHouse Patriot" with a woman, identified in court documents only as "Person 1." The person, Tenney and two other men did an interview on the night of Jan. 6 in a hotel room, wearing masks to conceal their identity, according to an FBI interview with another unidentified person in the room. Before the riot, Tenney had discussed "armed militia patriots" on Facebook and said they might besiege the building. Court documents state he wrote to Person 1 on Dec. 14, 2020, asking where he could get involved with "one of these patriot revolution groups like proud boys or any of the other American patriot militias." The person promised to ask around.

On Jan. 6 inside the Capitol, Tenney had several confrontations with officers, the FBI concluded, including an incident whereTenny pushed an officer to the side as he was coming in the East Rotunda doors.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty June 30, 2022 to civil disorder and obstruction of an official proceeding.

blurbs.text: Interfering with law enforcement officers during civil disorder; obstruction of Justice/Congress; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty June 30, 2022 to civil disorder and obstruction of an official proceeding.

characters.name: Chad Clifton
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Clifton bragged about his trip to the Capitol at work and shared a photo of himself inside the building with coworkers, at least five tipsters and witnesses told the FBI. The witnesses also said he went to the Capitol with his neighbor, Dave Johnston. One witness told the agency on Jan. 18, 2021 that Clifton had posted, then deleted, videos on Facebook and TikTok. One video showed him picking up trash after garbage cans was spilled inside the Capitol. Clifton wore maroon-colored shoes and a red Trump hat.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: David Charles Johnston
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Johnston went with his neighbor, Chad Clifton, to the Capitol, where the pair was spotted on video by people who know Clifton. Johnson wore a knitted cap with the word Trump on it and a circular 45 logo, according to the FBI.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Uliyahu Hayah
characters.title: Le Mon Williams
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers or employees; civil disorder; knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or ground without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging physical violence in a restricted building or on restricted grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; engage in an act of physical violence in the Grounds or any Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings.
characters.description: Hayah appeared in numerous videos inside the Capitol, and talked with a reporter afterward, saying he was with a group that "pushed all the way through." The Sedition Hunters, a group of volunteer sleuths working to help the FBI identify suspects, tipped off agents. Court documents show Hayah wore a camouflage backpack, black hat and gas mask and spent about 43 minutes in the building. He's seen in surveillance footage in Statuary Hall and near the Speaker's Lobby minutes after Ashli Babbitt was shot by law enforcement. He got into a confrontation with an officer working to force people out of the building. Hayah was on parole, supervised by the Virginia Department of Corrections for a criminal conviction in Maryland.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers or employees; civil disorder; knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or ground without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging physical violence in a restricted building or on restricted grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; engage in an act of physical violence in the Grounds or any Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings.

characters.name: James Douglas Rahm III
characters.charge: Obstruction of Justice/Congress; knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

image.alt: Photo of James Douglas Rahm III

characters.description: Rahm accompanied his father James Douglas Rahm Jr. to the Capitol, according to the FBI. On Feb. 4, 2021, agents served search warrants at two residences owned by Rahm Jr., one in Atlantic City and another in Philadelphia. In a video conference, Rahm told the FBI that he separated from his father, met friends and went with them into the Capitol Rotunda and into House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office suite, all while shooting video. He appears on surveillance footage inside the building. Court documents state Rahm's video shows him at the front of a group overpowering Capitol Police officers to force the doors open from the inside to let people in. His video also captures his father, also arrested, entering the building. Court records show he recorded a Snapchat video saying, "we just stormed the Capitol." His father messaged a friend to say his son had video of him urinating in Pelosi's office suite.

blurbs.text: Obstruction of Justice/Congress; knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Rodney Kenneth Millstreed
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; assault by striking, beating or wounding; simple assault; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description:
Millstreed is accused of picking up a pole and throwing it, javelin-style, at Capitol Police officers, striking one. Court records state he also picked up a smoke grenade thrown by law enforcement and threw it back at the officers. He is also among several charged with assaulting a member of the news media on Jan. 6. The Associated Press has reported that Millstreed is accused of assaulting is AP photographer John Minchillo. Court documents state Milstreed grabbed Minchillo by his backpack and pulled him down the stairs. He was identified as No. 156 on the FBI's BOLO list of violent offenders during the riot.

While he was at the Capitol, he sent photos of blood on the floor and added: "Man I've never seen anything like this. I feel so alive." He messaged another friend: "We are gonna take the building." An acquaintance reported to the FBI that Milstreed claimed allegiance to the Proud Boys. Court documents show a search warrant for Millstreed's Facebook account revealed messages that he'd posted before the riot saying things were going to get ugly and "I hope we don't have to hurt anyone." The FBI stated he also shared photos of weapons laying on a bed, including two assault weapons, two upper receivers, several loaded magazines and multiple large boxes of ammunition.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; assault by striking, beating or wounding; simple assault; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Michael Pomeroy
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
Pomeroy was charged with Brian Korte and Lynwood Nester, two other members of a political group called FreePA. Its website states its members are "patriots volunteering together to restore and protect our rights and freedoms by using action, action, action!"

Court documents state he was in the building for about 20 minutes, entering and leaving from the same door as the other Free PA members, Brian Korte and Lynwood Nester. Two other members of the group, William Blauser and Pauline Bauer, were arrested last year. Blauser identified the people with him in a group photo. Court records state Pomeroy's sister Sandra Pomeroy Weyer was also charged in the Capitol riot last year.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Lynwood Nester
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
Nearly 18 months after the U.S. Capitol riot, Nester was elected by voters in Pennsylvania's Monaghan Township to the county's Republican Committee. Less than a week later, the FBI charged him and two other members of a political group called FreePA, with participating in the riot. The group's website states its members are "patriots volunteering together to restore and protect our rights and freedoms by using action, action, action!" Two other members of the group, William Blauser and Pauline Bauer, were arrested last year. Blauser identified the people with him in a group photo.

Court documents state Nester and Brian Korte entered the building at about 2:40 p.m. on the second floor and went up a stairway to the third floor and remained in the building for about 10 minutes. The third recently arrested FreePA member is Michael Pomeroy.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Brian Korte
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Korte was charged in May 2022 with two other members of a political group called FreePA. Its website states its members are "patriots volunteering together to restore and protect our rights and freedoms by using action, action, action!" Two other members of the group, William Blauser and Pauline Bauer, were arrested in 2021. Blauser identified the people with him in a group photo. Court documents state Korte and Lynwood Nester entered the building at about 2:40 p.m. on the second floor and went up a stairway to the third floor and remained in the building for about 10 minutes. The third recently arrested FreePA member is Michael Pomeroy.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Linwood Alan Robinson Sr.
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

image.alt: Photo of Linwood Alan Robinson Sr.

characters.description:
While trying to identify people in photos, the FBI matched Robinson's photo to a booking mugshot from 2019 and matched him to a phone number used inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. FBI agents visited Robinson on May 17, 2021. By interviewing someone who knew the Robinson family, the FBI identified four other members of the family who were with him inside the Capitol, including his two sons, Linwood II and Benjamin Scott, daughter-in-law Brittany Nicole (married to Linwood Jr.) and a grandson, who was not identified or charged in the documents. The agents also found a photo on Facebook of the family at a family wedding.

The family entered the building at 2:17 p.m., five minutes after the initial breach, according to the FBI's Statement of Facts, then went down the hall to the Crypt, and were part of a group that breached the police line to get to the rest of the building. They walked toward the House Wing Door, then up a small spiral staircase to a corridor west of the Rotunda to the House Speaker's office. After walking through the suite for a few minutes, they left by a different door, walked through statuary hall, and then confronted a Capitol employee with a group of rioters, asking where the bathrooms were.
