characters.name: Jamie Lynn Ferguson
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Just a week after the riot, the U.S. Air Force Office of Special Investigations handed the FBI a report about Ferguson, a member of the West Virginia National Guard, saying she was suspected of unlawfully entering the Capitol on Jan. 6. The investigation and an FBI interview concluded she took leave to travel to D.C. with her mother and father. She's seen in video footage from the Capitol wearing a dark blue hooded sweatshirt with the phrase "Yes, I'm a TRUMP GIRL" in white letters. Court records show she spent almost an hour inside the Capitol. Before the riot, Ferguson had posted on social media regarding Jan. 6, including sharing an image of the Capitol with a storm cloud and Mt. Rushmore above the building with a caption that stated "Jan. 6, 2021 - A Storm of Patriots will fight for the Republic, this will be an historic day." She stated on the post: "I pray this is exactly what DC will look like on Jan 6th."
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty July 6, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty July 6, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Douglas Farquhar Macrae Jr.
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

image.alt: Photo of Douglas Farquhar Macrae Jr.

characters.description: Macrae posted photos on Facebook that he took while inside the Capitol, and one of his Facebook friends sent a tip to the FBI on Jan. 7, 2021. The FBI interviewed Macrae on Jan. 28, 2021 and April 12, 2021, when he admitted he went inside the Capitol building.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty July 19, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty July 19, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Devin Kiel Rossman
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: An anonymous tip on the day after the riot led the FBI to Devin Rossman, whose number also popped up on the list of unauthorized numbers used that day inside the building. Rossman had shared a photo of himself standing on the Capitol balcony on social media. After getting a search warrant for his Facebook account, the FBI discovered private messages in which he admitted entering the Capitol and the offices of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Conlin Weyer
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI identified Weyer after determining that his cell phone was used inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, then verified his identity by interviewing someone he knew in high school.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Robert Flynt Fairchild Jr.
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; engaging in physical violence in the grounds or Capitol building; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; obstructing or impeding an official proceeding.

image.alt: Photo of Robert Flynt Fairchild Jr.

characters.description: In body camera footage, the Department of Justice concluded Fairchild was seen moving up and down the police line along the security barriers on the west plaza, where he grabbed the gate and attempted to wrest control away from an officer. He later pushed the barriers into a line of officers and helped the crowd carry a barrier away. He was inside the building for about 20 minutes, according to the investigation, and participated in a group in the crypt who chanted "Fight for Trump."

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; engaging in physical violence in the grounds or Capitol building; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; obstructing or impeding an official proceeding.

characters.name: John George Todd III
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

image.alt: Photo of John George Todd III

characters.description: In March 2021, Todd was in a bar in Lee's Summit, Missouri and showed another bar patron a video of himself inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, including footage of him smoking marijuana. The witness later reported to the FBI that Todd said that weeks before the riot he was invited to D.C. by a friend who asked if he wished to "wreak havoc" at the Capitol. The friend paid for Todd's airline ticket. Body-worn camera footage shows Todd, wearing a bright red "Make America Great Again" hooded sweatshirt and screaming obscenities at officers, as well as smoking inside the rotunda.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty on May 11, 2022 to obstructing or impeding law enforcement officers.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty on May 11, 2022 to obstructing or impeding law enforcement officers.

characters.name: David Joseph Gietzen
characters.charge: Civil disorder and aiding and abetting; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; assaulting resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: A federal grand jury indicted Gietzen in April 2022. Tipsters identified Gietzen to the FBI after one of them spotted his wanted photo on Reddit, and then agents found him in multiple images taken at the Capitol on Jan. 6 where he wore a green jacket, jeans, knee pads and a while helmet and goggles, court records state. One image shows him grabbing and pushing an officer's shield. Other images show him pushing against officers and striking an officer in the shoulder with a pole. According to court records, Gietzen was involved in the melee at the Capitol for nearly 90 minutes.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder and aiding and abetting; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; assaulting resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: William Todd Wilson
characters.charge: Seditious conspiracy and obstruction of an official proceeding.
characters.description:
Wilson, a member of the Oath Keepers since 2016 and leader of a chapter in Sampson County, North Carolina, was the third member of the group to plead guilty to seditious conspiracy and obstruction charges. A military and law enforcement veteran, Wilson admitted he agreed to take part in a plan to use force to prevent, hinder and delay the transfer of presidential power, messaging back and forth with Oath Keepers leader Stewart Rhodes and others for weeks after the election. On Nov. 5, 2020, Rhodes urged Wilson and others to reject the presidential election results and said "We aren't getting through this without a civil war. Too late for that. Prepare your mind, body, spirit."

Records show that in a message on Signal on Dec. 30, 2020, Wilson posted, “Things are about to get real . . . and we need to be ready as ever!” On Jan. 5, 2021, he responded to a message about unrest after the next day’s Congressional proceeding, and replied, “That’s why I have all my gear with me.” His "gear" included an AR-15-style rifle, a 9-millimeter pistol, about 200 rounds of ammunition, body armor, a camouflage combat uniform, pepper spray, a walking stick and a pocketknife. On Jan. 6, he left the firearms and ammo in a hotel room, left his pepper spray and large walking stick in a car nearby and carried his pocketknife, but was prepared to retrieve the weapons if necessary, according to a statement of offense. He rode to the Capitol with Rhodes, who had stated that quick reaction force teams were stationed nearby and would be ready and waiting "in case of worst-case scenarios."

Wilson entered the Capitol at 2:34 p.m. through the Upper West Terrace Doors, the first of his co-conspirators to breach the building; and remained inside for about 21 minutes. The department stated he threw his cell phone into the ocean in January 2021 to prevent law enforcement from finding any incriminating evidence. The records state Wilson and others continued to plot to oppose the lawful transfer of presidential power by force even after the riot. At the Phoenix Hotel on the night of Jan. 6, Rhodes, in a group with Wilson and others, called an individual on speaker and implored him to tell President Trump to call upon groups like the Oath Keepers to forcibly oppose the transfer of power, but the person denied Rhodes’ request to speak directly to the president. In a Signal message, Rhodes wrote: "Patriots entering their own Capitol to send a message to the traitors is NOTHING compared to what's coming."

blurbs.text: Seditious conspiracy and obstruction of an official proceeding.

characters.name: Kimberly Wargo
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds (two counts); violent entry and disorderly conduct (two counts).
characters.description: Kimberly Wargo and her son Colton traveled to D.C. for the rally for President Trump and then walked into the Capitol and spent about 30 minutes inside walking around, court documents show. Court records state several surveillance photos seem to show Wargo leading her son around the Capitol.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds (two counts); violent entry and disorderly conduct (two counts).

characters.name: Colton Wargo
characters.charge: Entering or remaining inany restricted building or grounds (two counts); violent entry and disorderly conduct  (two counts).
characters.description: Colton Wargo and his mother Kimberly Wargo were arrested nearly a year after he was first interviewed about his activities inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. He told the FBI that he and his mother drove to D.C. for the rally for President Trump and then walked through an open door into the Capitol, then left after police yelled at them. Court records state they spent about 30 minutes inside the building.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining inany restricted building or grounds (two counts); violent entry and disorderly conduct (two counts).

characters.name: Edward Kelley
characters.charge: Assault; obstruction of law enforcement; destruction of government property; unlawful entry and physical violence; violent entry, disorderly conduct and other offenses.
characters.description: Kelley was involved in an altercation with an officer outside the Capitol, where he and two other men shoved an officer to the ground. Afterward, he found a board and used it to bash in a window, court records state. He wore a MAGA cap, a tactical-style backpack, helmet and gas mask. He was the fourth to enter the Capitol through that broken window. He then kicked open the Senate Wing door to allow other rioters to enter the building, and remained in the building for about 40 minutes, the FBI concluded in its investigation. The FBI reported it was assisted in its investigations by provided photos and videos. Agents tracked Kelley's purchase of a hoodie he was wearing in photos at the Capitol on Jan. 6 with a logo for a group that held prayer vigils outside a Planned Parenthood office in his hometown, Maryville, Tenn.

blurbs.text: Assault; obstruction of law enforcement; destruction of government property; unlawful entry and physical violence; violent entry, disorderly conduct and other offenses.

characters.name: Justin Michael Smith
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Smith carried a flag on Jan. 6, 2021 that read in part: "Trump 2020 The Sequel, Make the Liberals Cry Again," according to court records. He was identified through the FBI's search of cell phone numbers used in the Capitol that day. The FBI indicated additional information, including photos and video, was provided by a confidential source who doesn't know Smith, as well as two other witnesses who do know him.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Chad Heathcote
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; parade, demonstrate or picket in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Witnesses told the FBI that Heathcote bragged on social media about being in D.C. to "stop the steal," then quickly took down his accounts the next day. The FBI stated he was identified through cellphone records obtained from devices used at the Capitol on Jan. 6. The FBI said Heathcote is seen in video talking to two Capitol Police officers, then walking into the Capitol through a door opened by another rioter.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; parade, demonstrate or picket in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jennifer Horvath
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; other offenses on Capitol grounds.
characters.description: Jennifer Horvath appears in photos and video wearing a Trump sweatshirt and a "Trump - Keep America Great 2020" ball cap, dressing up a bust of Winston Churchill inside the Capitol with a hat and glasses, court documents state. She traveled to D.C. with her boyfriend Glenn Wes Lee Croy, who was previously arrested and pleaded guilty in August of 2021. She was identified through a search of cell phone numbers used in the Capitol on Jan. 6, with information found on Croy's cell phone, and an interview with the FBI. Court documents state Horvath, Croy and his friend Terry Lynn Lindsey entered the Capitol twice.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty August 12, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; other offenses on Capitol grounds.
Pleaded guilty August 12, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Joshua Colgan
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI found Colgan through its search of phone records for numbers active in the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Court records show that in an August 2021 interview, Colgan told FBI agents he traveled to D.C. to hear President Trump's speech then he went to the Capitol but did not enter the building, however, the FBI found security footage and other video showing Colgan inside the building. In a subsequent Facebook post, Colgan called the events of the day "the start of a revolution" and expressed his support for President Trump.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Matthew Montalvo
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in a Capitol building.
characters.description: A Florida real estate salesman, Montalvo is seen in surveillance videos and body camera video taken inside the Capitol, where he remained for more than 25 minutes, the FBI stated in court records.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Barry Bennett Ramey
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds with intent to impede or disrupt; knowingly engaging in an act of physical violence while using or carrying a deadly or dangerous weapon; act of physical violence in the grounds or Capitol building; assault of federal law enforcement officer with a deadly or dangerous weapon; obstruct, impede or interfere with law enforcement officer.
characters.description: Barry, identified as No. 329 on the FBI's wanted list, can be seen on body camera video spraying a chemical toward U.S. Capitol police officers as rioters were pushing against a group of officers trying to protect the Capitol building, according to the Department of Justice. He was a member of the Proud Boys in South Florida. A Statement of Facts by the FBI reported that after an agent left a business card with an associate of Ramey's, Ramey called the agent and asked if the agent still lived at a certain home address. The caller then disconnected but texted the agent with a VIN number associated with a vehicle the agent had previously owned.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds with intent to impede or disrupt; knowingly engaging in an act of physical violence while using or carrying a deadly or dangerous weapon; act of physical violence in the grounds or Capitol building; assault of federal law enforcement officer with a deadly or dangerous weapon; obstruct, impede or interfere with law enforcement officer.

characters.name: Jerry Braun
characters.charge: Obstruction during civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building; violent entry or disorderly conduct.
characters.description: After listening to President Trump's speech, Braun helped knock over barricades, argued with law enforcement officers and used an eight-foot-long plank to strike a news photographer twice, according to a federal complaint. An Uber driver picked up a bloodied Braun about a mile away from the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Braun told the Uber driver that he'd torn down barricades at the Capitol, then fallen and busted his head while walking away. Court records show that when the driver asked why he did it, Braun said so they could get to the Capitol. "Well, how'd that work out for ya?" the driver asked. Braun replied: "Well, it looks like, uh, Biden's gonna be our president." The Uber driver tipped the FBI. When agents showed up at Braun's home with a search warrant in November, Braun showed them the clothing he wore and admitted he was guilty of "everything."

blurbs.text: Obstruction during civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building; violent entry or disorderly conduct.

characters.name: Matthew LeBrun
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in a Capitol building.
characters.description: LeBrun is listed as a co-defendant in the Justice department's case against Florida resident Steven Miles. The FBI stated the two men marched with a group to the Capitol, including Zachary Johnson and Dion Rajewski, who have also been charged with participating in the riot. Records state LeBrun and Miles were involved in the violent melee on the west terrace. The FBI obtained information on LeBrun through a search warrant on the phone records of another Jan. 6 defendant, who was not identified in the court documents. A witness who took selfies with LeBrun and Steven Miles on Jan. 6 called in a tip to the FBI. LeBrun wore a tactical vest with a Three Percenters logo on it, according to the photo provided by the FBI.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Steven Miles
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; destruction of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Miles and Matthew LeBrun marched with a group of men to the Capitol, including other Jan. 6 defendants Zachary Johnson and Dion Rajewski. Miles fought with police officers and was part of a group that smashed windows near the Senate Wing door, court documents state. The Justice department said he smashed a wooden plank into a window, then entered the building through that broken window, walking through the building briefly before leaving through a door. Miles wore camouflage pants, a backpack, gloves and a "Make America Great Again" ballcap. A witness who took selfies with Miles and LeBrun called in a tip to the FBI.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; destruction of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Carson Lucard
characters.charge: Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: Lucard first entered the Capitol alone and lingered for around 15 minutes, according to a statement of offense he signed as part of a plea agreement with federal officials. The second time he went into the Capitol, he entered with a friend who had traveled to D.C. with him for the rally. He went into Senator Jeff Merkley's office, then took a selfie with his friend, Brian Stenz, in the Crypt. Documents state he was in the building for a total of about 23 minutes. Stenz was charged in May 2021.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty March 25, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced June 24, 2022 to 36 months’ probation with 21 days intermittent confinement (served in 3 intervals of 7 days each), 60 days home detention and $500 restitution.

blurbs.text: Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
Pleaded guilty March 25, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Sentenced June 24, 2022 to 36 months’ probation with 21 days intermittent confinement (served in 3 intervals of 7 days each), 60 days home detention and $500 restitution.

characters.name: Cale Douglas Clayton
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; theft of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in the grounds or a Capitol building.
characters.description: During a March 15, 2021 interview with the FBI, Clayton told an agent he was arrested on Capitol grounds on Jan. 6 while trying to return a police baton to the police, but that he had not participated in any violence or vandalism and no charges were filed. However, court records state the FBI later found police body camera footage taken at 4:15 p.m. that showed Clayton holding a baton and grabbing an officer's riot shield as officers were trying to clear the upper west terrace after hours of confrontation. At around 4:30 p.m., while officers were trying to take Clayton into custody, he grabbed an officer's face shield and pushed the officer backward, the FBI stated. He was arrested at 4:32 p.m., still holding the baton, court documents show. Earlier in the footage, he's shown yelling and shouting at police officers. Among the statements included in the documents are: "We are going to win. You don't have enough for all of us." He was also seen shouting: “You guys realize your President told us to be here. Your President! Hey, how does that make you feel? You’re defying your own (expletive) country."

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; theft of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in the grounds or a Capitol building.

characters.name: Anthony Michael Mazzio Jr.
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.

image.alt: Photo of Anthony Michael Mazzio Jr.

characters.description: Mazzio entered the Capitol within about two minutes of the first breach and remained in the building for almost an hour, the FBI concluded during its investigation. He wore a camouflage jacket, pants and ball cap, black tactical vest and gloves and a gas mask and carried a Trump flag. The FBI also reported that a British television reporter interviewed Mazzio inside the Capitol. Documents state he mentioned that he thought the rules had been changed mid-game and that he thought Hillary Clinton should be jailed. He also stated: "We want these people to be held accountable to the laws that we have seen them violate. That's all there is to it."
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty June 24, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty June 24, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Joshua E. Johnson
characters.charge: Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: When Johnson was arrested and charged with domestic assault in Spokane, Washington on July 19, 2021, he admitted to the FBI that he was the man dubbed #Metrojack by online sleuths helping officials to identify people who participated in the Capitol riot. He told the FBI agents that he wanted to "stop the steal," and hoped to find Congress in session and stand there and be heard by Congress. He also said he wanted to convince Vice President Pence to "do the right thing" and call out the "funky business going on with the votes." Court documents state he booked a one-way ticket to D.C. on Jan. 4 and told relatives he did not know when he would return. Photos in court documents show he wore brown overalls and a red plaid shirt and carried a gas mask and a cell phone. The photos were matched to previous booking photos and to a photo provided by two of Johnson's family members during an interview with the FBI. That photo had appeared in The New Yorker and showed him using his cell phone to take pictures of documents on a podium on the Senate floor.

blurbs.text: Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Brian Raymond Jones
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: A tipster told the FBI that Jones and Patrick John King appeared in a photograph on Facebook smoking marijuana inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, according to court records. Investigators reviewed security camera footage and found footage of men matching the appearances of Jones and King inside the Capitol, including the pair standing together in the Rotunda. Agents also used cell phone records to place the men in or near the Capitol. Google records showed they searched “Is it illegal to go into the Capitol” the evening of Jan. 6.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Patrick John King
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: King went to the Capitol “to punk Congress,” he said in a Facebook messenger chat obtained by the FBI. He also said he “smoked weed” and “was part of rushing riot police” in the messages, according to court documents. A tipster told the FBI that King and Brian Patrick Jones appeared in a photograph on Facebook smoking marijuana in the Capitol and agents found security camera images that appeared to be the two men inside the building on Jan. 6, 2021. Cell phone records also place the men in or near the Capitol that day, the FBI said.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: John Lammons
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Shortly after the Capitol riot, the FBI received screenshots from a WhatsApp account linked to Lammons discussing entering the Capitol during the riot. “After we left, some idiots came in and did some stupid things but the first group was totally professional,” one message says. Agents traced the phone number on the account to Anaconda Jiu-Jitsu, where Lammons is the owner. Lammons told agents there was no resistance when he entered the Capitol, according to court records. But he said he had to leave via a window because of a battle at the front doors.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jacob Zerkle
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: Zerkle was identified as No. 335 on the FBI's most-wanted list of Capitol rioters. Court documents state he appeared on video physically battling several uniformed officers with the Metropolitan Police Department, including throwing punches at one, pushing another and grabbing the baton of a third. He was identified by his large "mutton chops" facial hair. Zerkle and a family member drove from Arizona to D.C. to protest about election integrity, the court documents state. He told the FBI he "did not attend former President Trump's speech because he went to the Capitol to protest, not to listen to speeches." When he was shown photos from body-camera footage, he said he "probably did something dumb." He also said he was shoved into the police and was trying to protect himself but did not attempt to assault a police officer.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Jeffrey Munger
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Munger admitted to the FBI that he entered the Capitol through a broken window, and that he saw people trying to force open doors and heard glass breaking, according to court records. He said the window was his only way to leave the area because the crowd behind him was pushing him into a corner. Wearing a ballcap with a U.S. flag, he took photographs, then walked through the hall and left. The documents state he told the FBI he never heard any commands to leave the building.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty May 20, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty May 20, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jacob Elias Garcia
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The Burleson Texas Police Department reported Garcia's Facebook comments to the FBI. He had posted a video on Dec. 21, 2020 with the caption "Get Ready DC." His Facebook activity showed that he posted about "rigged" voting machines on Dec. 14 and searched for the Stop the Steal March on Dec. 23, the FBI reported. In a post on Jan. 7, he wrote: "MY ONLY REGRET IS NOT GETTING SOME SOUVENIRS." Court documents show the FBI also searched the website seditionhunters.com to find photos and videos of Garcia. A friend told the agency that Garcia's interest in QAnon ideology and conspiracy theories had changed his behavior.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Melanie Archer
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Archer and Jordan Bonenberger traveled from Pennsylvania to the rally and were seen together in multiple videos inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, court documents state. A tipster identified the pair to the FBI. According to surveillance video, the pair was inside the Capitol about 20 minutes.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jordan Bonenberger
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Bonenberger and Melanie Archer traveled from Pennsylvania to the rally and were seen together in multiple videos inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, court documents state. A tipster identified the pair to the FBI. According to surveillance video, the pair was inside the Capitol about 20 minutes. Media outlets in Pennsylvania reported that Bonenberger was a reservist in the U.S. Marine Corps.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Riley Kasper
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a deadly or dangerous weapon to inflict bodily injury; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description:
Kasper appears in videos deploying pepper spray or bear spray at officers and can be heard describing throwing items at law enforcement officers, court documents stated. "So we can't really say we were peaceful," Kasper said on one video. Agents used booking photos from his arrests in Wisconsin in 2015 and 2019 to verify his identity and talked with one of his former high school classmates. On Jan. 2, 2021, he shared on social media a photo poster of President Trump, with the words Trump had posted on Twitter that the Jan. 6 protest "will be wild." Then, on Jan. 6 and 7, he sent numerous messages to friends describing his exploits in the Capitol.

He wrote: "I pepper sprayed 3 cops so bad they got undressed and went home, gently brazed many others several times. I basically organized my own little militia and we (expletive) took over Congress." He went on to say it was his group "that busted the first gate and kept chasing the cops down and pushing them back into the capital(sic)." In a Jan. 7 message, he wrote: "Then fought cops all day got pepper sprayed more times than I can count, maced, hit with batons and (expletive) shot and then kept going..." He encouraged a friend to go back with him for the inauguration. "Idk you just gotta come next time. It's pretty exciting. It's like the most real version of paintball ever. But with pepper spray, flash bangs and tear gas grenades to throw back at those (expletives). And a huge team of people who all got your back. And will beat the cops off of you if they ever get ahold of you."

In another message he wrote: "...there is definitely something satisfying about pepper spraying cops in riot gear and watching them run from you like a (expletive) even though they have face masks, billy clubs and full (expletive) body armor."

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a deadly or dangerous weapon to inflict bodily injury; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Nancy Barron
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: "Made it in," Barron exclaimed in a selfie video taken inside the Capitol that the FBI recovered from Facebook after serving a warrant for the records, court documents state. She filmed for four minutes as she narrated with expletive-laden dialogue. At the end of the video, she walks up a set of stairs near the House Chamber and yells "(Expletive) Nancy Pelosi and (expletive) Chuck Schumer. Got to drag those (expletive) down." The next day, she called the FBI to report she was inside the Capitol. Court records state she falsely alleged to the FBI during an in-person interview on Jan. 11, 2021 that she was pushed into the building and that she attempted to find an exit as soon as she entered.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: John David Ross Gould
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; entering or remaining on the floor of Congress; violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

image.alt: Photo of John David Ross Gould

characters.description: Gould took a selfie in a mirror in the Rayburn Reception Room in the Capitol and texted it to his friend Jonathan Laurens, who was arrested in June 2021 on charges related to the riot, court records show. The FBI found the photo of Gould on Laurens' phone. Gould wore a green jacket and a white cowboy hat that said "Team Trump." According to court documents, the two men appeared together on video and spent about 40 minutes inside the Capitol.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; entering or remaining on the floor of Congress; violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jared Paul Cantrell
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Tipsters who knew Jared Cantrell and Quentin Cantrell, and who saw Jared Cantrell's social media posts about the riot led to the arrest of Jared, Quentin and Eric Cantrell. Jared Cantrell posted that he did not push past any officers and told himself he'd only go in until he met resistance, according to court documents. He wrote that to him, it seemed like police were letting the protesters in unless they tried to damage or take property.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Eric Andrew Cantrell
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Eric Cantrell went to the Capitol with his cousins Jared Cantrell and Quentin Cantrell, the FBI reported. The FBI concluded the cell phones of all three had been used in the Capitol that day.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Quentin G. Cantrell
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Quentin Cantrell went to the Capitol with his cousins Jason Cantrell and Eric Cantrell, the FBI reported. The FBI reported he attempted to climb down a wall on the West Terrace as Eric Cantrell reached down to help him.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Mandy Robinson-Hand
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI tracked down this Georgia couple, Charles Hand and Mandy Robinson-Hand, after learning their cell phones were used at the Capitol that day. The pair appeared on surveillance footage and other video that day. A witness told the FBI that Robinson-Hand posted on Facebook that they were in the Capitol "taking our house back."

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Charles Hand III
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI tracked down the husband-and-wife pair of Charles Hand and Mandy Robinson-Hand learning their cell phones were used at the Capitol on Jan. 6. The pair appeared on surveillance footage and other video that day. A tipster reported to the FBI that Hand posted about the riot on Facebook, saying he was "an eye witness of the storming" of the Capitol. He also wrote that he saw thousands of angry Americans "marching onto the Capitol to protest and stop the certification of what I personally believe to be an election stolen from the American people."

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Raul Eduardo Jarrin
characters.charge: Remaining in a restricted building with intent to impede or disrupt official functions; disorderly or disruptive conduct on the Capitol grounds; parading in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Jarrin attended the rally, then was inside the Capitol for about 15 seconds, according to court records. He was identified through an FBI investigation into phone numbers used at the Capitol on Jan. 6. He provided the FBI with a photo of the clothes he was wearing that day, but included a red knit cap. The FBI stated that in the photos he was wearing a red ball cap instead. From surveillance footage, it appeared he stepped inside the door, took photos and then left.

blurbs.text: Remaining in a restricted building with intent to impede or disrupt official functions; disorderly or disruptive conduct on the Capitol grounds; parading in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Ralph Joseph Celentano III
characters.charge: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

image.alt: Photo of Ralph Joseph Celentano III

characters.description:
Celentano is seen on video walking up to a Capitol Police officer from behind on a west terrace, making physical contact and causing the officer to fall over a several-foot ledge, according to the FBI investigation. The officer, an Iraq war veteran, told the FBI he was tackled from behind without warning. A photo in the charging documents shows the officer falling into a crowd of officers. Celentano also was observed in several other physical altercations with uniformed officers on Capitol grounds, court documents stated.

Celentano's photo was added to the FBI's most-wanted list. Witnesses who had worked with a sea turtle foundation recognized Celentano as a participant in a fundraiser.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Lloyd Casimiro Cruz Jr.
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI identified Cruz because his phone was one of many detected in the Capitol building that day that didn't match the numbers of people who were authorized to be in the building. In an interview, Cruz said he saw President Trump's speech, then marched down Pennsylvania Avenue then watched U.S. Capitol personnel remove the lower barriers to allow people to get closer to the building, according to court documents. Then Cruz said he watched people pull away upper barriers, and he assumed those people were with Antifa. Although Cruz initially told the FBI he went up the steps but did not go inside the building, he later said that after looking at his video he remembered he did go inside the building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Iraj George Javid
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI credits a confidential informant and the Sedition Hunters, a collective group of online sleuths helping the FBI to track down the identities of individuals seen in the Capitol on Jan. 6, with identifying Javid. Javid was pictured as No. 301 in the FBI's photos of rioters, court documents state. The FBI confirmed Javid's identity with friends and acquaintances and found that his cell phone was active inside the Capitol that day. Javid has a Virginia driver's license and was employed by the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty August 12, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty August 12, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Narayana Rheiner
characters.charge: Civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Rheiner had been dubbed "#LynyrdSinner" by online sleuths trying to figure out his identity. The FBI had assigned the No. 384 to photos of him on their most wanted list. After seeing a photo of Rheiner on bodycam video, the FBI interviewed an officer who remembered Rheiner as someone trying to hurt officers and get past the police line.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Geoffrey Samuel Shough
characters.charge: Civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading , demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Video showed Shough at the Capitol waving a Texas flag and wearing an orange jacket, which earned him the name #TexasPleather from internet sleuths helping to identify accused rioters. He wore the jacket over a body armor vest with a ballistic-style helmet, goggles and hard knuckle gloves, according to the FBI. He was identified as No. 256 in the FBI's most wanted photos. Tipsters who identified him connected the FBI with Shough's ex-girlfriend. Shough was among the first few people to breach a line of uniformed police officers who were trying to prevent the rioters from entering the building. The FBI said a search of his bank records revealed a $129.99 payment to the Oath Keepers in December 2020.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty August 16, 2022 to civil disorder.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading , demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty August 16, 2022 to civil disorder.

characters.name: Carol O'Neal Kicinski
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted  building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: Kicinski is the founder of Simply Gluten Free, a gluten-free lifestyle and recipe blog and bills herself as "America's Gluten Free Voice." She was featured for several seasons in guest episodes on a nationally syndicated NBC television show based in Tampa, "Daytime." Authorities say she and Jon Heneghan traveled from their home in Dunedin, Florida to D.C. and entered the Capitol through the Senate Wing doors. Based on the FBI's search of surveillance footage, the couple was in the building for less than 15 minutes. The pair was tracked through cell phone numbers traced to the Capitol on Jan. 6.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building

characters.name: Jon Nicholas Heneghan
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted  building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: The FBI verified Heneghan's identity by showing photos to his ex-wife. Court documents show he and Carol Kicinski, a nationally known gluten-free lifestyle blogger, traveled from their home in Dunedin, Florida to DC and entered the Capitol through the Senate Wing doors, remaining in the building less than 15 minutes. The pair was tracked through cell phone numbers traced to the Capitol on Jan. 6.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building

characters.name: Matthew Thomas Krol
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds.
characters.description:
The self-professed executive officer of the Genesee County Volunteer Militia pushed his way through the crowd on the Capitol steps, threw a water bottle at police officers and pulled other people out of his way, the Department of Justice stated in a news release. Then Krol grabbed an officer of the Metropolitan Police Department, wrested away his police baton and used it to strike other officers, investigators concluded based on photos, body camera footage and video clips, including one provided by sedition hunters.org. He was identified as No. 291 in the FBI's wanted photos of violent offenders.

Investigators said Krol was seen in media reports during the Flint, Michigan water crisis, where volunteer militia members handed out free bottled water and water filters. A Detroit Free Press story in 2016 quoted him, saying he was wearing full camouflage and a handgun, saying the militia wasn't going to allow the government "to step on the people of Flint any longer."

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds.

characters.name: Joshua Lee Hernandez
characters.title: Ace
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding officers; civil disorder; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; enter and remain in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; enter and remain in a gallery of either house of Congress; disorderly or disruptive conduct in any of the Capitol buildings with the intent to impede, disrupt and disturb the orderly conduct of a session of Congress and either House of Congress; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: Wearing a red hat and a "Trump 2020 (expletive) your feelings" hoodie, Hernandez was identified in some of the very earliest photos released by the FBI. Carrying a U.S. flag, he was dubbed No. 27 in the bureau's most-wanted photos of violent offenders.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding officers; civil disorder; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; enter and remain in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; enter and remain in a gallery of either house of Congress; disorderly or disruptive conduct in any of the Capitol buildings with the intent to impede, disrupt and disturb the orderly conduct of a session of Congress and either House of Congress; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building

characters.name: Athanasios Zoyganeles
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description:
Three different tipsters reported Zoyganeles to the FBI after he posted photos and videos on Facebook discussing his attendance at the Capitol riot. The agency's investigation found that he discussed attending the riot in messages with a Facebook friend. In one message, he said, "It's time we take this country back." He told a friend later that he had been "on the front lines."

"It wasn't easy but we did it," he stated, describing that he'd been sprayed with teargas and mace. After obtaining photos of him inside the Capitol, court records show the FBI met with a close family member of Zoyganeles, who identified him in the photos.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty July 1, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
Pleaded guilty July 1, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Vincent Gillespie
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Gillespie, wearing a sweatshirt for a Pittsfield, Massachusetts fitness club, was seen among rioters in the melee on the Capitol's lower west terrace, struggling through the crowd and maneuvering through the rioters to the line of police officers guarding the doors, federal officials said. Court records say he's seen on body camera footage using a police shield to ram officers, while screaming "traitor" and "treason," and also grabbed an officer by the arm and tried to pull him into the crowd. He was identified through tips to the FBI Boston office, including tips from a former neighbor, who recognized his photo, and employees of the town of Athol where he frequently attends meetings.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Mark Waynick
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; loud, threatening or abusive language, engaged in disorderly or disruptive conduct and acts of physical violence in a Capitol building; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers.
characters.description: Waynick and his son Jerry wore helmets, tactical vests and tactical gloves to the Capitol and entered the building through the upper west terrace, according to court records. The pair were involved in the rioters' efforts to break the perimeter line officers set up on the west front of the Capitol, court records state. Surveillance footage and body camera footage show them in the building for 25-30 minutes, including in the Senate wing, the rotunda, statuary hall and the House wing.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; loud, threatening or abusive language, engaged in disorderly or disruptive conduct and acts of physical violence in a Capitol building; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers.

characters.name: Jerry McKane Waynick
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; loud, threatening or abusive language, engaged in disorderly or disruptive conduct and acts of physical violence in a Capitol building; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers.
characters.description: Waynick, a student at Nashville State Community College, attended the Capitol riot with his father Mark Waynick. The pair wore tactical helmets, vests and gloves to the Capitol and were seen in multiple instances inside the building on surveillance footage and body camera footage, court records show. A Dickson County Tennessee sheriff's deputy who said he had previously had multiple interactions with the Waynicks reported them to the FBI. Court documents state the pair rushed the line and pushed toward officers who set up a perimeter at the Capitol, and Jerry Waynick is shown on video trying to grab an officer's baton. The younger Waynick is shown throwing a barricade at officers.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; loud, threatening or abusive language, engaged in disorderly or disruptive conduct and acts of physical violence in a Capitol building; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers.

characters.name: Reva Vincent
characters.charge: Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Reva Vincent was charged by information and ordered to attend an arraignment/plea agreement hearing on March 23, 2022.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty April 22, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty April 22, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Leticia Vilhena Ferreira
characters.charge: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
characters.description: Ferreira is a citizen of Brazil, living in Illinois. Court records state she's on a work visa and was unable to vote, but followed the news of the 2020 election. She flew to Washington DC and went to the rally to hear President Trump speak, wearing a Michael Kors camouflage colored jacket and a red "Trump" beanie. Investigators reported she said she was unable to see or hear his speech so she walked with the crowd to the Capitol and went in. Court records show Ferreira messaged with someone the next day: "I was so irresponsible to walk there. I was with this nice family. This gentleman and two sons. Pacific walking." In another message she said: "I'm so irresponsible. Yesterday it felt amazing." She also texted the person that she didn't realize there were barriers up to prevent people from going in until she saw them after the riot.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty June 22, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
Pleaded guilty June 22, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Katharine Hallock Morrison
characters.charge: Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: In February 2022, Morrison was added to an indictment with Dale Shalvey and Tara Stottlemyer, who had previously been arrested. Shalvey was accused of stealing a letter from Utah Senator Mitt Romney to Vice President Mike Pence.

blurbs.text: Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Shelly Stallings
characters.charge: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
characters.description: Stallings was arrested a year after her husband, Peter Schwartz, was also arrested on charges related to the Capitol riot. Stallings, Schwartz and two others are charged in an indictment with using pepper spray on a line of police officers trying to establish a secure area on the Capitol's lower west terrace.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings

characters.name: Matthew Beddingfield
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Beddingfield is shown in video jabbing at and striking officers with an American flag attached to a metallic flagpole. In court documents, the FBI credits the work of online sleuths in helping to identify Beddingfield, who was on probation for a criminal conviction in North Carolina while at the riot.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jake Maxwell
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: Maxwell stands accused of struggling with a Capitol Police officer and a Metropolitan Police Department officer, the Department of Justice stated in a news release. He was identified on the FBI's list as No. 474. Court documents state the FBI received confidential tips that Maxwell was engaged in the physical confrontations and identified him on surveillance video. During an interview with the FBI in Atlanta in December, Maxwell admitted to being the person in the photos but said he didn't remember doing those things, and was under the effects of being sprayed with an irritant and started "freaking out."

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Eric Gerwatowski
characters.charge: Civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading or demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
Gerwatowski is listed as No. 244 in the FBI's photo directory of rioters wanted for assaulting officers, and he was dubbed #lordlonghair by the online sleuths that have been feeding information to the FBI. The agency matched a photo shared in February 2021 by the Twitter user @RavenDragon2015 to a photo previously posted by Gerwatowski on an Instagram account. Tipsters also advised the FBI that Gerwatowski told associates that he'd been inside the Capitol.

At one point, court documents show, Gerwatowski reopened one of the Upper House Doors just after an officer shut it and yelled to the crowd "Let's go!" A Capitol police officer interviewed by the FBI said he had just come from the area where Ashli Babbitt was shot, and he was exhausted, outnumbered, and had already been attacked and sprayed with several chemicals.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading or demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jolene Eicher
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: Former high school classmates and a coworker turned Eicher over to the FBI after seeing her in a Business Insider news photo taken inside the Capitol. Witnesses told the FBI she had worked for Prince Edward Virginia Rescue Squad but left her job after the Capitol riot. After searching her Facebook account, the FBI reported that one friend asked Eicher to describe what she saw in the Capitol in 3-5 words. Eicher wrote: "What. The. Crap. Woohoo!!!!!!!" The FBI stated phone records showed she was in the vicinity of the Capitol from 1:16 p.m. to 4:45 p.m. and that surveillance video showed she crawled through a window at the Senate Wing Door at 3:22 p.m.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
