characters.name: Markus Maly
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: Maly was No. 324 in the FBI's photo directory of rioters wanted for violence against law enforcement or the news media. The FBI stated it matched those photos with booking photos the agency found in Virginia. He was seen on body camera footage spraying something from a canister toward police officers. Wearing a Trump cowboy hat, court records show he's pictured in photos in the violent melee on the lower west terrace. On Jan. 7, 2021, he commented on a Facebook post stating: "There were lots of pissed off patriots there and we wanted our voices to be heard. I myself one(sic) of them. We were there to support President Trump and the voting process." According to court documents, he told his girlfriend it was "so fun."

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Kenneth Rader
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: A relative of Rader's turned him into the FBI, saying he had been "radicalized" and was sharing videos of himself inside the Capitol and had "articulated a full rage(sic) of threats against VP Mike Pence." In February 2021, Rader changed his Facebook cover photo to show a large Q, signifying QAnon. Court documents indicate Rader told the FBI in an interview that he did not enter the Capitol, but he was seen inside the building on security footage for about three minutes.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty June 7, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.description: Blythe is accused of participating in attacks with a metal crowd control barrier against Capitol Police officers at the Peace Circle. One of the officers suffered injuries.

characters.name: Juliano Gross
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: Two different internet sleuths provided information to the FBI about Gross, based on their own research, reporting he had posted on TikTok while inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. Gross attended President Trump's speech with his mother, and then he continued on to the Capitol, according to federal charging documents. In one video, Gross stated: “We are in the Capitol Building. Power back to America. We are in the Capitol Building. The Capitol Building has been overthrown. It has been overthrown.”
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty July 29, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.description: Armstrong admitted on Facebook that he was inside the Capitol and people who saw the posts tipped the FBI, according to court documents. While he was in the building he said he sang the Star Spangled Banner and talked to Capitol Police officers.

characters.description: The FBI identified Anthony and Jeremiah Carollo through their phone records after their numbers were detected inside the Capitol grounds on Jan. 6. The brothers traveled to D.C. with their cousin, Cody Vollan, also charged. According to court records, Vollan and Jeremiah Carollo admitted in separate interviews with the FBI that they were inside the Capitol on Jan. 6.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty April 21, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Kirstyn Niemela
characters.charge: Enter and remain in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct to impede a session of Congress; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Niemela told friends she was a member of the Proud Boys and that "something big" was going to happen, according to at least three different tipsters who talked to the FBI. One witness told the FBI that Niemela shared a video of a window being broken at the Capitol. She was identified in photos with Stefanie Chiguer, who a witness told the FBI was Niemela's girlfriend. They both wore an American flag as a cape and a black sweatshirt that stated "We the People ARE PISSED OFF." A search of the telephone of Michael Eckerman, also charged in the riot, found messages to Niemela with photos on Jan. 6.

blurbs.text: Enter and remain in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct to impede a session of Congress; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.charge: Enter and remain in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct to impede a session of Congress; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Authorities identified Chiguer after several witnesses reported Kirstyn Niemela's Facebook posts. Witnesses told the FBI that Chiguer was Niemela's girlfriend. The pair wore matching sweatshirts and American flags tied around their shoulders like capes in photos the FBI provided in charging documents.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty April 7, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.description: A tipster reported Schaefer to the FBI the day after the riot, sharing images he had posted to his Facebook page. One post, shared in a screenshot in court documents, stated he had been teargassed 10 times. Video footage from the Capitol shows he was in the building for about 28 minutes, the FBI concluded.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty August 2, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Alan Fischer III
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding officers using a dangerous weapon; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; violent and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building.
characters.description: Fischer marched to the Capitol on Jan. 6 with members of the Proud Boys, according to the Department of Justice. Then he joined others in the fracas on the Capitol's west side. Rioters pushed against the officers to try to get into the building. He was later seen on the west front, where he threw chairs, a traffic cone and a pole toward officers, the department stated in a news release.

characters.description: An indictment stated Rajewski carried pepper spray in the Capitol building.

characters.charge: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Edward Vallejo
characters.charge: Seditious conspiracy; conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties
characters.description: Vallejo is charged with Oath Keepers founder Stewart Rhodes and nine others with seditiously conspiring to overturn the election of Joe Biden as president. Federal prosecutors say Vallejo was one of the leaders of the Oath Keepers' "quick reaction force" in Washington D.C. on Jan. 6. While other members of the group marched into the Capitol in military formation, prosecutors say, Vallejo's group was waiting just outside the city with weapons, ready to respond if others called them in.

blurbs.text: Seditious conspiracy; conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties

characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Knutson is a conservative rap artist, who performs as Playboy the Beast, has 15,000 subscribers and 1.7 million views on Youtube. A tipster told the FBI that Knutson had posted photos of himself at the Capitol, and another source provided a video clip of Knutson entering the building through a window.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty April 13, 2022 to entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds.

characters.name: Frank Rocco Giustino
characters.title: "Frankie"
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Giustino was identified to the FBI by a former classmate who recognized him in a newspaper photo of the Capitol riot. The agency further identified him in surveillance video and obtained messages he posted on the instant messaging platform, Discord.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Andrew Galloway
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Someone sent the FBI a Tik Tok video Galloway recorded, saying: “Yeah, that was us today; no that wasn’t Antifa." Wearing a winter hat with the word "Trump" on it, Galloway appeared to enter the Capitol through a breached window and leave through another breached window after spending about 10 minutes in the building, according to charging documents. The documents show Galloway lives in Cody, Wyoming and has a Wyoming drivers license. His Facebook page states he lives in Tennessee. He is listed in Wyoming records as the owner of Powderkeg Patriots Apparel, where the paperwork was filed in November 2020 and amended with a Wyoming, P.O. box in November. The company is a screen printed Tshirt business launched in May 2021. Among the items offered are Tshirts that state: "When the people fear the government that's tyranny. When the government fears the people, that's liberty" and "Rebellion against tyrants is obedience to God."
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty, March 9, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty, March 9, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Nicholas John Lattanzi
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Lattanzi came to the attention of the FBI in December 2020, after posting a Tik Tok video that was reported to the agency. Charging documents state he had added the caption: "New jacket who wants to commit war crimes in Bosnia with me?" The FBI was watching Lattanzi's social media accounts to see if he posted about the Capitol riot, according to charging documents. He posted a video on Tik Tok on Jan. 6, with a photo of himself wearing a brown cowboy hat with a gold Burger King paper crown around it. He had a "Pine Tree flag," white with black lettering tied around his shoulders like a cape. The flag has been linked to a squadron of ships under George Washington's command during the Revolutionary War. In an April 5 interview, he told the FBI he wasn't in the Capitol, but someone claiming to represent him sent a letter the very next day seeking an opportunity to amend the first statement. On April 21, he admitted he entered the building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Thomas Uberto
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Charging documents indicate Uberto was inside the Capitol for less than 10 minutes, citing surveillance footage, which pictured him wearing a red winter hat with the word "Trump" and a "Stop the Steal" T-shirt.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: John M. Cameron
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Cameron was in the Capitol for about 20 minutes, according to an FBI review of surveillance camera footage. Just two days later, a tipster reported his identity to investigators, based on posts he had made to Facebook. In security photos, he's wearing a red ball cap with the words "Make America Great Again," a white Tshirt that states "Count All Legal Votes," and an American flag as a cape.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty May 4, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced August 15, 2022 to 36 months of probation, including 30 days of intermittent confinement, $1,000 fine and $500 restitution.

characters.name: James Wayne Brooks
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Brooks wore a military style vest and a ball cap with the words "veteran" and "Iraqi Freedom" to the Capitol riot, according to federal charging documents. Brooks' sister told the FBI that he served two tours of duty in Iraq. The FBI indicates he was seen in surveillance video and on police body camera footage, and he carried a two-way radio.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty August 4, 2022 to entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Robert Snow
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Snow spent about 45 minutes in the Capitol before being escorted from the building by Capitol Police, federal charging documents show. In an interview, he admitted he was in the building that day.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty March 24, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced July 7, 2022 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours community service and $500 restitution.

characters.name: James Robert Elliott
characters.title: Jim Bob
characters.charge: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers with a dangerous weapon; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly and dangerous weapon; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
characters.description: Elliott was charged with five felonies, after the Department of Justice said he used a flagpole to assault officers on the Capitol grounds.

characters.name: Mason Joel Courson
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds;
characters.description: Courson is named in the third superseding indictment among a group of men charged with assaulting law enforcement officers.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds;

characters.name: Lucas Denney
characters.charge: Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct
characters.description:
Federal charging documents detailed conversations between Lucas Denney and Donald Hazard discussing the events leading up to and after the riot. The men were members of a group called the "Patriot Boys," a self-proclaimed militia group. Denney identified himself as the president and appointed Hazard as the sergeant at arms, saying he was buying him other gear to wear in addition to a helmet and vest. Denney also said they were buying police-grade pepper spray from the Fort Worth police store.

On Dec. 25, Denney exchanged messages with Hazard saying his trip to the big Jan. 6 rally would be paid for if he wanted to go. He wrote: "Tell your boss you're going to do your part saving the country from communist(sic)." The FBI reported that Denny worked to raise funds for the trip and recruit others. In one message, the agency reported, Denney wrote: "So Trump has called this himself. For everyone to come. It’s the day the electoral college is supposed to be certified by congress to officially elect Biden. But, Pence is in charge of this and he’s going to throw out all the votes from states that were proved to have fraud. There’s so much more going on behind the scenes though. That’s why he’s called this rally for support. . . . Trump will stay President . . . .That’s why I’ve been super busy. I’m the President of the Patriot Boys in North Texas and have over 200 guys. We are 3%ers. Since I’m retired from the military this is what I do mainly."

The FBI reported documenting numerous incidents of Denney fighting police officers, including battling officers with a long metal pole and launching a large tube toward officers. At other points in the melee on the west terrace, Denney is seen in footage carrying a metal baton, forcing a shield against officers and dragging another officer down the stairs.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty March 17, 2022 to assaulting, impeding or resisting certain officers using a dangerous weapon.

blurbs.text: Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct
Pleaded guilty March 17, 2022 to assaulting, impeding or resisting certain officers using a dangerous weapon.

characters.name: Paul Lee Seymour Sr.
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds (two counts); violent entry and disorderly conduct (two counts)

image.alt: Photo of Paul Lee Seymour Sr.

characters.description: This father and son duo went into the Capitol together, were ushered out of one door but then went in through another open door. Seymour Jr. told the FBI that officers lined the hall but made no attempt to prevent them from entering, instead greeting them by saying "Have a good day" or "How are you," according to the charging documents. They estimated they spent about an hour looking around inside. Two people tipped the FBI to their participation in the riot.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty July 14, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds (two counts); violent entry and disorderly conduct (two counts)

characters.name: Brent John Holdridge
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Holdridge was identified after the FBI began searching the list of phone numbers used in the Capitol on Jan. 6. Using a California jail booking mug from an unrelated Feb. 23 case, agents searched surveillance footage of the Capitol and found Holdridge in those videos, on one of the west terraces, holding a flag, according to federal charging documents. Agents also confirmed his cell phone number with his probation officer.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty August 4, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty August 4, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jeffrey William Hubbard
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: When a Lincoln City Police Department detective visited Hubbard's residence in an unrelated investigation on Jan. 7, 2021, his mother told officers he was at the Trump rally in Washington D.C. FBI agents looking through videos taken inside the Capitol spotted Hubbard and were able to confirm his identity with the Lincoln City Police. In one video, he stands behind Audrey Southard-Ramsey, the Florida music teacher charged with participating in the riot, as she confronts officers inside the building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jared Kastner
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI discovered Jared Kastner's phone was in use at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and did not match the records of any phones that were lawfully allowed inside the Capitol that day. According to charging documents, his identity was confirmed by a former work supervisor. They also determined that one of his most frequent phone contacts, Luke Faulkner, was also at the Capitol that day. Inside the building, at one point, the men walked together, with Faulkner's hand on Kastner's shoulder and Kastner's hand on the shoulder of someone wearing a big white cowboy hat.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Michael Oliveras
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: On. Jan. 8, a tipster wrote to the FBI about a Parler user: "This individual has been talking about overthrowing the government for weeks in public chat rooms pushing disinformation and talking about hanging and executing people repetitively." The tipster said the individual also claimed to be in the Capitol on Jan. 6 and was sharing "multiple disturbing videos." The FBI used that information to track down Oliveras, according to charging documents. Two other individuals also reported Oliveras to the FBI. On the day of the riot, Oliveras posted multiple videos and messages on Parler. He wore a red sweatshirt with the word "Trump" on the front, a red hat with white lettering and carried a U.S. flag.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Freedom Vy
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct
characters.description: Vy is one of a group of Proud Boys members from Pennsylvania charged with participating in the Capitol riot. The others included Brian Healion, Zachary Rehl and Isaiah Giddings. Federal charging documents state they posed for a photo on the upper west terrace and went into the office of Senator Jeff Merkley of Oregon.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct

characters.name: Jonas Buxton
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
A tipster told the FBI that Buxton quit his job and went into hiding after the FBI began announcing the arrests of Capitol rioters. That tip and others led the agency to investigate further and find that Buxton's phone was used inside the Capitol that day. Federal charging documents state that on April 7, when Buxton landed in Miami on a flight from Panama, Customs and Border Protection officers interviewed him, searched his phone and found photos of him wearing a tactical vest with a Trump patch. In one he's holding a weapon while standing in front of a Christmas tree. Buxton is seen on surveillance footage in the Capitol wearing the tactical vest and a gas mask and carrying a yellow flag.

Customs officers also found a letter in his phone, a call to action for the Jan. 6 rally from the Three Percenters. The call to action advised members not to wear tactical gear. It stated: "We are not going there to fight; we are going there to peacefully protest."
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty August 10, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty August 10, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Thomas Paul Conover
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
Conover regularly updated his Facebook posts on his Jan. 6 plans. He agreed to go in a comment on a post by Kevin Blakely on Dec. 12. Later, according to federal charging documents, Conover and Blakely were seen together in surveillance footage from the Capitol on Jan. 6. Later in December, Conover invited others to join and said he was going to D.C. on the 5th, to "join the mob." On Jan. 6, he poted: "We took the Capitol."

But the very next day, according to the FBI, he posted: "The Capitol was not stormed the people walked in." The FBI carefully matched Conover's selfies inside the Capitol to the surveillance footage, including one where he's drinking a can of Coors. In one video he took on Jan. 6, according to the charging documents, Conover stated: "I pray to God that nobody does any damage to the stuff in here, 'cause I'm not down with that. But, I'm kind of, kind of proud of the people that stood up and said you know what? Enough. You don't see people spray painting (expletive) or burning (expletive) down. It's really kind of cool. I'm glad I came."
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Jan. 7, 2022, to disruptive conduct at a restricted building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced April 22, 2022 to 36 months probation, including 30 days at a residential reentry center, 60 hours of community service, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty Jan. 7, 2022, to disruptive conduct at a restricted building.
Sentenced April 22, 2022 to 36 months probation, including 30 days at a residential reentry center, 60 hours of community service, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution.

characters.name: Luke Faulkner
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Faulkner was one of the most frequent contacts in Jared Kastner's phone, the FBI stated in charging documents. The two men are seen together inside the Capitol in surveillance footage, Faulkner's hand on Kastner's shoulder and Kastner's hand on the shoulder of someone wearing a big white cowboy hat. The FBI identified the pair through finding that Kastner's phone had been in use at the Capitol that day.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Roy Nelson Franklin
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; obstruction of an official proceeding.
characters.description: Franklin was featured in an interview in the publication "Insider" on Jan. 7, where he described what he saw in the Capitol and said the day had been "fun." An FBI agent who saw the story checked public records and found an address for Franklin and drove by his home on Jan. 8. Franklin was at the Capitol with Thomas B. Adams, who was previously arrested, according to charging documents. The pair were just feet away when the Jacob Chansley, clad in the horned helmet and furs, reciting a prayer on the floor of the Senate. The clothing Franklin wore was seized in April, when the FBI served a search warrant on the house where he lives. In a December interview with the Chicago Sun-Times, Franklin is quoted as saying: "I got arrested for supporting Trump.”

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; obstruction of an official proceeding.

characters.name: Donald Hazard
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, resulting in significant bodily injury; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds resulting entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol; disorderly conduct in the Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in the Capitol building.
characters.description:
A tipster told the FBI that Hazard posted a photo of himself on Facebook, “breaking into the [U.S. Capitol] bldg” and telling people to come down and help "‘storm the building like a true patriot." Federal charging documents detailed conversations between Hazard and Lucas Denney discussing the events leading up to and after the riot. The men were members of a group called the "Patriot Boys," a self-proclaimed militia group. Denney identified himself as the president and appointed Hazard as the sergeant at arms, saying he was buying him tripes to wear in addition to a helmet, vest and other gear. Denney also said they were buying police-grade pepper spray from the Fort Worth police store.

On Dec. 25, Denney exchanged messages with Hazard saying his trip to the big Jan. 6 rally would be paid for if he wanted to go. He wrote: "Tell your boss you’re going to do your part saving the country from communist." The FBI reported that Denny worked to raise funds for the trip and recruit others. Documents show Hazard was seen on video inside the Senate Parliamentarian's office. He is accused of fighting with officers at the Capitol, including fighting with one officer and pulling him down the steps as they fell. The officer was knocked unconscious.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, resulting in significant bodily injury; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds resulting entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol; disorderly conduct in the Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in the Capitol building.

characters.name: Brian Healion
characters.charge: Unlawful entry on restricted building or grounds; violent entry; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
characters.description: Healion is one of a group of Proud Boys members from Pennsylvania charged with participating in the Capitol riot. The others included Freedom Vy, Zachary Rehl and Isaiah Giddings. Federal charging documents state they posed for a photo on the upper west terrace and went into the office of Senator Jeff Merkley of Oregon.

blurbs.text: Unlawful entry on restricted building or grounds; violent entry; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds

characters.name: Avery MacCracken
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: After being alerted by tipsters, local law enforcement officers recognized photos of MacCracken that were on the FBI's most wanted list for Capitol violence because they were already familiar with him, according to federal charging documents. The officers concluded that MacCracken is homeless, but residing in Telluride, Colorado. The FBI stated the tipster was making use of the Sedition Hunters website to help track people down. MacCracken is accused of punching a law enforcement officer in the eye.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Tim Levon Boughner
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building
characters.description: Boughner was spotted among a crowd of rioters at the Capitol. At approximately 2:33 p.m., he used a chemical spray against officers, the Department of Justice stated in a news release. People in the crowd were throwing objects and deploying multiple chemical sprays against law enforcement officers attempting to secure the building. One minute later, Boughner again used the chemical spray against the officers. In a social media post on Jan. 6, he stated that he “started spraying” at the Capitol and “f---- those cops up.” On Feb. 17, he posted, “I have to share. My life has not been the same since this day … I still don't know how I ended up on the capital steps having a pepper spray fight with the capital police.”

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building

characters.name: Justin Jersey
characters.charge: Assault, resist, or inflict bodily injury on an officer; obstruct, impede and interfere with a law enforcement officer;  enter and remain in a restricted building and grounds; engage in disorderly conduct; physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; physical violence within the Capitol grounds or Capitol buildings.
characters.description: Jersey is one of a group of men accused in a superseding indictment with assaulting an officer with the Metropolitan Police Department. The indictment states he used a baton to assault an officer.

blurbs.text: Assault, resist, or inflict bodily injury on an officer; obstruct, impede and interfere with a law enforcement officer; enter and remain in a restricted building and grounds; engage in disorderly conduct; physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; physical violence within the Capitol grounds or Capitol buildings.

characters.name: Daniel Shaw
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; parading, picketing or demonstrating in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Shaw traveled to Washington D.C. with his son and allowed an acquaintance, Kenneth Reda, to share a hotel room with them on the night of Jan. 5. Reda, arrested earlier this year, talked with the FBI and pled guilty on Nov. 4 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building. Court records show Shaw was in the Capitol for about 14 minutes, based on the FBI's research of Jan. 6 video footage from the Capitol.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; parading, picketing or demonstrating in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Michael Gianos
characters.charge: Restricted building or grounds; violent entry or disorderly conduct
characters.description: Gianos exchanged messages with Rachel Myers and Larry Stackhouse in the weeks after the presidential election, the FBI stated in a complaint, discussing their belief that the presidential election had been stolen and a desire to stop the certification process. The messages included a shared tweet from President Trump, saying it was "statistically impossible" to have lost the election. The FBI said all three entered an office in House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's suite of offices, but only for about a minute. Gianos later messaged someone that he had "stormed" Pelosi's office.

blurbs.text: Restricted building or grounds; violent entry or disorderly conduct

characters.name: Mark Kulas
characters.charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: Kulas and his brother Christian traveled from Illinois to Washington to attend the rally, according to federal charging documents. They were in the Capitol for about 25 minutes.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Dec. 6, 2021 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced April 26, 2022 to six months supervised probation, including 60 days home detention, $500 restitution.

blurbs.text: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building
Pleaded guilty Dec. 6, 2021 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Sentenced April 26, 2022 to six months supervised probation, including 60 days home detention, $500 restitution.

characters.name: Danean Kimberly MacAndrew
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building and parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: MacAndrew's name came up when the FBI Los Angeles Field Intelligence Group conducted a review of unauthorized phone numbers that were detected in the Capitol on Jan. 6. FBI agents said when they interviewed her, MacAndrew said she marched to the Capitol after President Trump's speech, then said Capitol police were letting people into the Capitol building and she thought it was okay to go inside the building. Once inside the building, she said she walked around inside the Capitol building for a few minutes and then left when Capitol police told people they had to leave.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building and parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Rachel Myers
characters.charge: Restricted building or grounds; violent entry or disorderly conduct
characters.description:
A tipster reported Myers to the FBI on Jan. 12, saying she participated in the riot and shared a screenshot of a comment she posted on Facebook several weeks earlier saying she was OK with a civil war, according to federal charging documents. A second tipster told the FBI she is "a very fanatical Trump supporter." The FBI reported that cell phone records from Myers, Michael Gianos and Larry Stackhouse said the trio exchanged messages in the weeks after the presidential election discussing their belief that the presidential election had been stolen and a desire to stop the certification process. The messages included a shared tweet from President Trump, saying it was "statistically impossible" to have lost the election. The FBI said all three entered an office in House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's suite of offices, but only for about a minute. Gianos later messaged someone that he had "stormed" Pelosi's office.

On Jan. 8, Myers posted the following in a Facebook comment: “Girl I was there Wednesday, and NO RIOT ever happened. The media are absolute liars. The cops opened those doors for everyone to walk right into the Capitol," according to the FBI. She also messaged the following to another Facebook user: “Pence is a deep state traitor !!!!” and asked “Why would he set us up to come there. Tell us he was holding the lien and only count legal votes then put out a tweet in the middle of Trumps speech that he can’t change anything”

blurbs.text: Restricted building or grounds; violent entry or disorderly conduct

characters.name: Marcos Panayiotou
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Panayiotou, a U.S. Marine, moved from New Jersey to Pennsylvania in October 2020. A complainant told the FBI on Jan. 10 that Panayiotou went into the Capitol with his parents, but the FBI stated the agency had not been able to confirm whether his parents were in the Capitol. The Department of Defense confirmed that Panayiotou was assigned to the 1st Maintenance Battalion in Camp Pendleton, California, for the United States Marine Corps until approximately in or about February 2020. The FBI stated the records show he was released from active duty and became a member of the Marine Corps Reserve in May 2020. Charging documents state he wore a sweatshirt with the words "Reparable Management Company" and its logo, representing his unit at Camp Pendleton, and a red hat with the phrase "MAKE POLITICIANS AFRAID AGAIN." The documents also state a close family member told the FBI that he was "very patriotic but 'does stupid things sometimes.'"

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Matthew Jay Webler
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI traced a cell phone detected inside the Capitol to Webler and also found a Facebook post he made stating he'd been inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. Charging documents state the agency saw him on surveillance footage and that he was wearing a flag around his neck with the letter "Q" on it.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Dec. 30, 2021, to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced May 3, 2022 to 45 days in prison (time served) and $500 in restitution.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty Dec. 30, 2021, to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Sentenced May 3, 2022 to 45 days in prison (time served) and $500 in restitution.

characters.name: Isaiah Giddings
characters.charge: Unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
characters.description: Giddings is one of a group of Proud Boys arrested who exchanged messages before the rally. That included one on Jan. 5 from a "Person One," who requested their emergency contacts and blood type, according to federal charging documents. They corresponded with Zachary Rehl, who was president of the Philadelphia Proud Boys. The documents state Rehl stayed at the Darcy Hotel in D.C. on the night of Jan. 5 with Giddings, Brian Healion and Joseph Yeng, who the FBI stated is likely an alias for Freedom Vy. The men were part of a group of six men who posed for a photo on the Capitol's upper west terrace, which Rehl posted on Facebook on Jan. 7 with the caption "bad ass pic in DC." The documents state the men went into the office of Senator Jeff Merkley of Oregon.

blurbs.text: Unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds

characters.name: Josiah Kenyon
characters.charge: Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers.
characters.description: At the Capitol riot, Kenyon wore a Jack Skellington costume, a character from The Nightmare Before Christmas movie. The FBI stated he and others damaged an exterior window, and then used several objects, including an apparent table leg with a protruding nail to assault law enforcement officers.

blurbs.text: Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers.

characters.name: Ronald Loehrke
characters.charge: Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers or employees.
characters.description: At the time of the riot, Loehrke resided in Seattle, Washington, and the FBI reported he'd been in touch with Proud Boy Ethan Nordean. According to text messages recovered from his phone, Nordean told Loehrke he wanted him "on the front line with him." The agency stated he appears in video and still photos inside the Capitol in confrontation with officers.

blurbs.text: Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers or employees.

characters.name: James Haffner
characters.charge: Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers or employees.
characters.description: James Haffner was among the first rioters to get past various barricades at the Capitol, the Justice Department said in a new release. When Haffner climbed the stairs on the Capitol's East side, he raised his hand and sprayed an aerosol substance at the U.S. Capitol Police officers guarding the doors, the department said. He lived in Seattle at the time of the riot, then later moved to South Dakota.

blurbs.text: Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers or employees.

characters.name: Tyler Tew
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: Tyler Tew posted on Facebook that he was at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, a tipster reported to the FBI six days later. The FBI then found a post on Tew's page, which stated: "DC protests to be clear! There was absolutely zero vandalism aside from a broken door that I saw, I saw no fighting and only anger at our government for allowing an election to be stolen." Charging documents state Tew was seen on security footage entering through the Senate Parliamentarian door and looking inside the office of Senate Appropriations Committee Vice Chairman Richard Shelby. He was later sprayed by a pepper ball blast, the agency reported.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building

characters.name: Howard Richardson
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Richardson was recorded on video striking a Metropolitan Police Department officer three times with a metal flag pole before the pole broke in his hands, according to charging documents. The FBI noted Richardson was arrested in 2020 and again in September 2021 after being accused of assaulting a person riding a motorcycle outside his home. In an interview with the FBI, he admitted swinging the flagpole, but said he only swung it once after the officer swung a piece of metal at him.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty April 27, 2022 to assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty April 27, 2022 to assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers.

characters.name: Lawrence Ligas
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: Ligas was quoted by name on National Public Radio in a story about the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, and a former acquaintance reported it to the FBI five days later. A charging document reported Ligas was quoted saying: "We're not moving on. ... We are not Republicans. We are the MAGA party. We are patriots." The FBI connected him to a phone number that had been inside the Capitol, the same number Ligas had used to report voter fraud in March and April 2019. The agency also reported finding numerous selfie photos he'd taken inside the Capitol.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building

characters.name: Aiden Henry Bilyard
characters.charge: Civil disorder and aiding and abetting; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; destruction of government property and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description:
Charging documents for Bilyard describe the harrowing experience of a Metropolitan Police Department officer who said he was sprayed with bear spray on multiple occasions on Jan. 6 on the Lower West Terrace. Bilyard stands accused of one of those attacks, after an FBI agent located him on police body-camera video discharging a can of bear spray toward the officer. One officer standing near that officer was severely affected by bear spray exposure and was taken to a hospital for treatment. In another video, the FBI stated Bilyard was seen receiving a baseball bat from the crowd and handing it to a man who was trying to break a window.

But then Bilyard used the bat himself to break the window, encouraging the crowd to enter the Capitol through the window, according to the charging document. The window led to Senate Terrace Room 2 Mezzanine. The FBI stated people who entered the room through the window took items from the room that could be used as weapons, including table legs and lamps and passed them out to people through the broken window. Bilyard was dubbed "#HarvardSweats" by online sleuths helping to identify rioters because he was wearing a Harvard sweatshirt under a black puffy jacket, the charging documents state. Law enforcement officers located an unrelated, previous booking photo of Bilyard from May 2020.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder and aiding and abetting; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; destruction of government property and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Lisa Anne Homer
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building ; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description:
Homer flew to Washington D.C. on Jan. 3. Wearing a tactical vest, rings and a knitted cap with a patch stating "Lions Not Sheep," she is seen in Jan. 6 Capitol video footage chanting with William "Billy" Chrestman, one of the Proud Boys leaders. Homer moved extensively throughout the Capitol for about an hour, the FBI stated in a charging document, but the agency discovered no evidence that she destroyed property or assaulted officers.

The FBI found she posted an emblem associated with the Proud Boys on one of her social media accounts, and that she had visited Washington D.C. on Nov. 14, 2020 for the Million MAGA March and posted Proud Boys photos. Charging documents show she posted about that trip on Instagram in October 2021, adding this caption to a photo of a man: "Last November I was led to go to DC to stand for our liberties. Little did I know this guy would grab my hand that night. Miracles do happen." Although she was charged as Lisa Homer, the FBI stated she changed her last name to Boisselle in June, after a divorce. The Yakima Herald in Washington State reported she ran for the Yakima County Board of Commissioners as a Republican in 2018, but was eliminated in a primary.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty August 9, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced August 9, 2022 to three years of probation, 60 hours of community service, $5,000 fine and $500 restitution.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building ; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
Pleaded guilty August 9, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Sentenced August 9, 2022 to three years of probation, 60 hours of community service, $5,000 fine and $500 restitution.

characters.name: Bryan Emmanuel Bustos
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: A tipster alerted authorities Jan. 10 to Bustos' participation at the Capitol. Bustos posted a photo on Instagram while inside the building, the tipster told the FBI. Charging documents indicate the FBI matched Bustos' name and photo to California Department of Motor Vehicle records. Bustos, who was in the Capitol for about 11 minutes, was with Alexis Bustos, who entered the Capitol before him, according to the FBI's search of security footage.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building

characters.name: Alexis Ivan Bustos Campo
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building

image.alt: Photo of Alexis Ivan Bustos Campo

characters.description: Bustos traveled to Washington D.C. with Bryan Bustos, who has also been charged. The pair flew to D.C. via American Airlines on Jan. 3. He was in the Capitol for about 23 minutes.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building

characters.name: Edward Badalian
characters.title: Turbo
characters.charge: Conspiracy, obstruction of an official proceeding; tampering with documents or proceedings; entering restricted building or grounds.
characters.description:
Badalian is one of three men listed in a federal grand jury indictment who were members of a group on Telegram called "Patriots 45 MAGA Gang." The indictment also names Daniel Rodriguez, who was previously arrested, but the identity of a third participant was sealed. The indictment stated the men began in November 2020 to advocate violence against groups who supported the 2020 presidential election results and attended rallies in Huntington Beach and Beverly Hills supporting Trump and opposing COVID-19 mask mandates. It also alleges they altered, destroyed or concealed documents to impair their use in the grand jury investigation.

The indictment states Badalian talked to InfoWars under a pseudonym after the riot and then later told a fourth person unnamed in the indictment, "Person One," not to use his name when discussing the events at the Capitol because the person had used his first name when talking to InfoWars. On Jan. 8, the trio went to the home of "Person One," unplugged all Amazon Alexa devices and mimed the person should not speak out loud. The complaint alleges Badalian urged the person to get an external hard drive to download all the photos and videos from the person's phone.

blurbs.text: Conspiracy, obstruction of an official proceeding; tampering with documents or proceedings; entering restricted building or grounds.

characters.name: James Delisco Beeks
characters.charge: Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties; destruction of government property and aiding and abetting; entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; civil disorder and aiding or abetting.
characters.description:
Beeks is a Michael Jackson impersonator and an actor who portrays Jesus in the traveling Broadway show Jesus Christ Superstar. He's also one of the Oath Keepers who invaded the Capitol on Jan. 6 while marching in military formation, the FBI stated in a criminal complaint. Several groups began in November 2020 to plan and attend military-style training in preparation for opposing the results of the presidential election, the FBI stated.

Multiple groups coordinated their actions, and sent messages using social media trying to recruit as large a following as they could to go to Washington D.C. to interfere with the official congressional proceeding, the complaint said. One of the more detailed documents filed in recent months, the complaint listed a full timeline and noted many of the rioters were wearing tactical vests and helmets and carrying bear spray and eye protection. Beeks, however, was wearing a Michael Jackson "Bad" jacket and a black helmet. He carried a homemade black shield that he told someone on scene was bulletproof. The FBI obtained phone records for Beeks' iPhone 8 and his payments for hotel rooms in Georgia and North Carolina on his way to the Capitol.

The complaint stated he changed his phone number and the name used on his registration after the Ocala Star Banner and other media outlets reported in February that a group of Florida Oath Keepers had been indicted. The agency observed Beeks performing in Jesus Christ Superstar in San Francisco and Los Angeles. He was arrested in Milwaukee where he was scheduled to perform the week of Nov. 23.

blurbs.text: Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties; destruction of government property and aiding and abetting; entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; civil disorder and aiding or abetting.

characters.name: Michael McCormick
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: McCormick flew from Santa Ana, California to Washington D.C. on Jan. 5, and the FBI tracked his cell phone to the Capitol on Jan. 6, the FBI stated in charging documents. It appears the agency found him through his cell phone records. The FBI stated McCormick entered the building at 2:55 p.m., wearing a Trump 45 knitted winter cap, walked through the Crypt and Hall of Columns and left roughly eight minutes later.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty July 18, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty July 18, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Timothy Desjardins
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; entering restricted grounds with a dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in restricted buildings or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and demonstrating in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
Desjardins is accused of assaulting multiple law enforcement officers in the tunnel area of the Lower West Terrace of the Capitol, where some of the most violent conflicts occurred. The U.S. Attorney's office stated he appeared to use a broken wooden table leg. Desjardins was number 348 on the FBI's most-wanted list of accused Capitol offenders. He's among more than 210 individuals charged with assaulting or impeding law enforcement.

The FBI said it confirmed his identity through a scar on his face and an "Air Jordan" backpack that was recovered in Washington D.C. on the morning of Jan. 7, that matched photos taken the day of the riot. An officer also recognized Desjardins had been questioned that morning after attempting to go over the chains on E Street behind the FBI headquarters. At the time, the FBI stated, Desjardins had one or two hatchets tied to the backpack.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; entering restricted grounds with a dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in restricted buildings or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and demonstrating in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Robert Turner
characters.charge: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Robert Turner was named in a criminal complaint with Gregory Richard Purdy and Matthew Purdy, also of New York. Turner is Greg Purdy's uncle, according to the Department of Justice. A news release stated that at approximately 2:01 p.m. on Jan. 6, video footage footage shows Gregory Purdy and Turner in a crowd pushing the police line, both making contact with officers. The release stated Purdy, his brother, and Turner entered the Capitol at approximately 2:13 p.m. and remained there for at least a few minutes.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Mark Andrew Mazza
characters.charge: Illegal possession of a firearm on Capitol grounds; obstructing any official proceeding; obstructing law enforcement during civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers with a dangerous weapon; entering and remaining in any restricted building; engaging in disorderly or disruptive conduct;
characters.description:
Mazza took a Taurus revolver loaded with three shotgun shells and two hollow point bullets to the Capitol, the FBI alleged in court documents. A U.S. Capitol Police officer recovered the gun at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021 on the West Front Terrace at around 2:30 after striking a man with his baton.

On Jan. 8, Mazza filed "a false police report in Indiana" claiming to have lost his gun in an Ohio casino, but the department stated he later admitted to officers that he lost it from a shoulder holster at the Capitol. Charging documents also state Mazza lied to the officers about assaulting officers and about where the lost the gun. Mazza was seen on security footage entering the tunnel to the Lower West Terrace, and once the glass doors were breached held doors open to let rioters enter the building, the Department of Justice stated in a news release. Holding a baton, he assisted the group in pushing toward officers who were defending the area and joined in assaulting them, swinging the baton at police and yelling "This is our (expletive) house! We own this house!" the prosecutors stated.

In a voluntary interview, Mazza told officers that he "never did get to talk to Nancy." He continued: "I was glad I didn't because you'd be here for another reason and I told my kids that if they show up I'm surrendering, nope they can have me because I may go down as a hero."

blurbs.text: Illegal possession of a firearm on Capitol grounds; obstructing any official proceeding; obstructing law enforcement during civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers with a dangerous weapon; entering and remaining in any restricted building; engaging in disorderly or disruptive conduct;

characters.name: Gregory Richard Purdy
characters.charge: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Purdy took a bus to the Capitol, wearing a red, white and blue jacket and recorded at least 15 video clips of himself in the runup to the riot. In one, he talked to the camera while walking down a street with his father, Gregory Purdy-Schwartz, the FBI stated in charging documents. Also charged were his brother Matthew Purdy, and Robert Turner. In another video clip, Purdy states: "We're not letting this steal happen. We're not letting this travesty against democracy happen, because that's what it its. We're going to the Capitol right now, we're marching there." In a seventh clip, Purdy posted: "I got my Ass kicked by 10 cops, pepper sprayed, tear gassed, and a ripe ass beating with the Batons ... More info to come! Videos of inside the capital(sic) building with @mattcpurdy and @bobtheplumbr1982 ... I LOVE MY COUNTRY !!!!! STOP THE STEAL!!!!" Purdy was No. 66 on the FBI's photo list of Capitol riot suspects, and had been dubbed #BabyfaceInsider by online sleuths trying to help the FBI identify rioters.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Matthew Purdy
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Purdy traveled with is brother, his father and other family members to Washington D.C. according to court records. His brother, Gregory Purdy, filmed at last 15 video clips of himself during, before and after the rally and riot.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Rafael Valadez, Jr.
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Valadez livestreamed on Facebook his excursion into the Capitol on Jan. 6. He donned a large white cowboy hat, with the words Team Trump on the front, and posted photos of himself, including one captioned "A day to Remember," the FBI stated in charging documents.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty July 1, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty July 1, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jeremy Baouche
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: A tipster identified Baouche, an engineer who attended the University of Connecticut, a week after the riot, the FBI stated in charging documents. A co-worker told a task force officer that Baouche took off work on Jan. 5 and 6, saying he was going fishing with his grandfather. When contacted at work at Electric Boat, a Department of Defense contractor, Baouche, who had a secret security clearance, declined to be interviewed without an attorney. His employer provided the internet search history from Baouche's work computer, which showed he'd researched the Capitol layout, guns, rifle scopes and lasers, and finding a job in the West, charging documents stated. While trying to sort out varying stories from different witnesses, agents with an FBI task force watched video taken inside the Capitol and recognized Baouche, who was carrying a megaphone. He used it to lead a chant calling "whose house?" to which people responded, "our house." After serving a warrant on his phone, the FBI concluded he purchased the megaphone between Nov. 22 and Dec. 26.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Gregory Lamar Nix
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; destruction of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon
characters.description: Nix attacked a U.S. Capitol Police officer with a flagpole, including striking the officer on his head, and also used the pole to bang against a door and window, the FBI wrote in charging documents. Later, video shows Nix smashing the doors with a baton, stated the complaint, which added the agency also traced his cell phone to the building.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; destruction of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon

characters.name: Louis Valentin
