characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Valentin traveled with his friend and roommate Julio Baquero to Washington D.C. for the Jan. 6 rally, and admitted to the FBI in a March interview that they had entered the Capitol during the riot. Valentin told officers he and Baquero were in the building for only about 10 minutes. However, the FBI reported in the charging documents that the pair entered the Capitol at around 2:45 p.m. and left sometime after 3:05 p.m.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: David Charles Rhine
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
A post by Rhine's wife on Facebook that said she was proud her husband had entered the Capitol eventually led the FBI to him, after someone saved a screenshot of the post. Agents tracked his cell phone inside the building that day, the FBI stated in charging documents. According to a screenshot in the documents, in texts with an acquaintance, Rhine's wife said he was "nowhere near any of the violence." Then Rhine texted: "Thanks. I witnessed ZERO violence. I saw no 'proud boys'. Capitol police removed barriers and let people in." After the friend advised Rhine to turn over information, one of the Rhines texted back, saying: "True friends (family too) will back up the Rhine's" (sic).

After reviewing video footage, the FBI found that Rhine had been confronted by a Capitol Police officer, the documents stated. The officer searched him and found two knives and pepper spray, and placed Rhine in flex cuffs behind his back. The officer escorted Rhine to the Rotunda and told him he was releasing him, but did not take the flex cuffs off.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Julio Baquero
characters.charge: Civil disorder; assaulting resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Baquero and his roommate Louis Valentin traveled from Hollywood, Florida to Washington D.C. for the rally on Jan. 6 then went into the Capitol. Baquero told the FBI during an April interview that after he saw a person with a knife inside the Capitol, Baquero wanted to leave, and a police officer cleared a path for him to exit. However, the FBI reported a different story in charging documents. It stated Baquero could be seen in video footage resisting officers, grabbing the hand of an officer and later shouting, "You're a traitor." Further, the documents state, when officers were trying to close the doors of the rotunda, Baquero could be seen on video pushing the door open while officers are trying to close it.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; assaulting resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Daniel Michael Morrissey
characters.charge: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; knowingly engaging in disorderly or disruptive conduct in any restricted buildings or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds.
characters.description: A former co-worker alerted the FBI to Morrissey's presence at the Capitol after another coworker shared photos and text messages, according to charging documents. Morrissey took photos and video, during which the crowd can be heard shouting "USA" in the Capitol Rotunda.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Feb. 23, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced August 16, 2022 to 45 days of incarceration, three years of probation, $2,500 fine and $500 restitution.

blurbs.text: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; knowingly engaging in disorderly or disruptive conduct in any restricted buildings or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds.
Pleaded guilty Feb. 23, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Sentenced August 16, 2022 to 45 days of incarceration, three years of probation, $2,500 fine and $500 restitution.

characters.name: Thomas Patrick Hamner
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds
characters.description: Hamner is seen on video fighting with police over a police barricade on the west plaza at the Capitol just after 1:30 p.m. and pushing a large metal Trump sign into a line of officers, charging documents say. He wore a sweater with images of Christmas trees, flowers, assault-style rifles and an anti-Clinton statement.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty May 17,  2022 to civil disorder; all other charges remain pending.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds
Pleaded guilty May 17, 2022 to civil disorder; all other charges remain pending.

characters.name: Paul Colbath
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
A tipster reported Colbath to the FBI on January 11, 2021, saying he had bragged to family and friends about participating in the riot. The FBI interviewed him at his home on Jan. 22, when he told them he entered the Capitol through an open door and saw a cloud of tear gas. Colbath told the FBI he ushered a man affected by the tear gas into an office to get fresh air and noticed the office had a broken window and vandalism. He's seen on video assisting the man. Colbath said he was only in the office for about five minutes, then left the building to go back to his hotel.

When the officers arrived at his South Carolina home, Colbath told them he did not want to turn himself in because he didn't feel like he'd done anything criminal. But he told them it felt good to get it off his chest, and that he felt like going to the Capitol was "a big mistake."
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Jan. 10, 2022, to disruptive conduct at a restricted building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced April 6, 2022 to three years of probation, to include 30 days home detention, 60 hours community service,  $500 restitution.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty Jan. 10, 2022, to disruptive conduct at a restricted building.
Sentenced April 6, 2022 to three years of probation, to include 30 days home detention, 60 hours community service, $500 restitution.

characters.name: Jia Liu
characters.charge: Knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; engage in disorderly or disruptive conduct; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Liu is an active duty member of the U.S. Marine Corps Reserves as a cyber network operator assigned to the 6th Communication Battalion, according to charging documents. He was identified in photos by a Marine Corps Reserve officer. Federal charging documents state he is seen in security and body-camera footage entering the Capitol twice on Jan. 6, wearing an American flag hood.

blurbs.text: Knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; engage in disorderly or disruptive conduct; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Kim Michael Sorgente
characters.charge: Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building.
characters.description: Sorgente stands accused of battling against officers protecting the Capitol for about three hours during the Capitol riot, and was initially listed as No. 263 on the FBI's wanted list for the event. The FBI worked with the Santa Ana Police Department, which had arrested Sorgente on Dec. 20, 2020. Charging documents stated that Sorgente emerged from the crowd after rioters brought down the barricades on the west side of the Capitol at about 1:36 p.m. on Jan. 6. Wearing a red Make America Great Again ball cap, he carried a megaphone and a cell phone, and shouted at officers, calling them traitors, the FBI stated. He was again seen yelling at officers at 2:04 p.m. as officers tried to push back rioters, documents show, and seen in the crowd pushing back against police on the lower west terrace and at the an archway several times between 2:40 p.m. and 4:24 p.m. The FBI stated he was seen in police body-camera video at 4:24 p.m., as officers tried to move rioters away from the archway, yelling: "Oh god, don't do it. Oh my god, you hurt me bad! Please! Please! Ah, I got hit in the head. I'm bleeding now." As he pushed his weight into the officers, they continued to push against him for more than a minute. The documents state he was seen rinsing his eyes out with water after the officers finally pushed him away at 4:26 p.m. then returning to the fight at about 4:46 p.m.

blurbs.text: Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building.

characters.name: Gilbert Fonticoba
characters.charge: Civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Fonticoba was named in a four-count grand jury indictment filed Oct. 22, 2021, and arrested four days later in Miami.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Philip Weisbecker
characters.charge: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; knowingly engaging in disorderly or disruptive conduct in any restricted buildings or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds.
characters.description:
Federal officers explored Weisbecker's participation in the Capitol riot during a series of secondary inspections as he crossed the border between Mexico and the U.S. several times in February and March. Two confidential informants provided selfie photos to the FBI that Weisbecker had taken in the House Speaker's office during the Capitol riot, then shared. According to charging documents, the FBI reported he flew to Washington D.C. from San Diego on Frontier Airlines on Jan. 4. A review of publicly available posts on his Facebook account showed a screenshot from a Tucker Carlson program that showed Weisbecker inside the Capitol, the FBI stated.

U.S. Customs and Border Protection interviewed Weisbecker four times as he crossed from Mexico into the U.S. on Feb. 7, Feb. 10, Feb. 23 and March 3. During the first stop, he told officers he had traveled to Washington D.C. to participate in the "Stop the Steal" protest. He called officers names and yelled profanities during the Feb. 10 stop. Officers searched his phone during the Feb. 23 stop and discovered selfies of Weisbecker inside the Capitol. During the last stop, Weisbecker told officers he was tired of being harassed by "the communist officers."
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty March 3, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced June 27, 2022 to 24 months of probation with 30 days of intermittent incarceration on weekends, $2000 fine and $500 restitution.

blurbs.text: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; knowingly engaging in disorderly or disruptive conduct in any restricted buildings or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds.
Pleaded guilty March 3, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Sentenced June 27, 2022 to 24 months of probation with 30 days of intermittent incarceration on weekends, $2000 fine and $500 restitution.

characters.name: Robert Wayne Dennis
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: A Metropolitan Police Department officer identified Dennis as the man who assaulted the officer in the melee on the Upper West Terrace. The FBI stated that in videos from the scene, Dennis appears to place his hands on one officer, then grab the officer's baton and get turned sideways colliding with another officer. That turned into a violent struggle, the FBI stated, and the officer's baton was knocked out of his hands. Dennis is shown in police body-camera footage taking the officer to the ground, records show. Another officer reported seeing Dennis throw punches. Officers looked at his identification and told told him that they would apply for an arrest warrant at a later time. Officers released him to seek medical treatment the officers could not provide, the FBI stated.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Landon Bryce Mitchell
characters.charge: Obstruction of Congress; knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in any restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining on the floor of either house of Congress; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description:
Mitchell was seen wearing a Trump ball cap and camouflage jacket in photos with Luke Wessley Bender, who was arrested earlier this summer. The FBI stated Bender identified Mitchell and said they were former co-workers and had attended other rallies together. The men reportedly climbed the scaffolding and got onto the terrace where they went into the Capitol rotunda and then made their way to the Senate chamber.

According to screenshots of his Facebook account, Mitchell had posted angry messages about the presidential election. On Jan. 7, he posted an image of a skull in purple flames stating "Absolutely Proud of my fellow Americans who made their voices heard at the Capitol."

blurbs.text: Obstruction of Congress; knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in any restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining on the floor of either house of Congress; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building

characters.name: Joshua John Portlock
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
characters.description: Portlock is accused of attacking federal officers trying to protect the west side of the Capitol building on Jan. 6, the FBI said in court documents. Photos and video show Portlock among rioters who pushed through and then removed metal barriers as Capitol police tried to hold them back. Portlock and another man then used a piece of plywood to shove against and then on top of at least three officers, the FBI said. After that, Portlock was among rioters who assaulted police in the Lower West Terrace entrance to the Capitol. "On at least two occasions, Portlock participated in 'heave-ho' efforts, by which multiple rioters collectively used their body mass for greater effect in pushing back officers," agents wrote. Portlock arrived at the Capitol on Jan. 6 wearing a white cowboy hat with "Trump 2020" printed on it and, under that, a black beanie with a Proud Boys emblem, the FBI said.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings

characters.name: Jason Michael Comeau
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: A relative reported Comeau to the FBI on Jan. 12, saying the Florida man had admitted he entered the Capitol. However, the tipster reported Comeau was confused because he believed some Capitol Police officers told the crowd to enter the building and others had told them to stay out, the FBI reported in charging documents. In an interview on Jan. 18, the FBI said Comeau stated he walked toward the Capitol after President Trump's speech and that police officers let people in after the crowd began to chant "Let us in." The FBI located Comeau inside the building in security footage and police body-camera video. The FBI also reported that Comeau said he never went farther than a hallway but is seen in video in the Statuary Hall connector among the group that had advanced toward the doors leading to the House chamber chanting, "stop the steal."
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Dec. 21, 2021, to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty Dec. 21, 2021, to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: James Grant
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: Grant was one of two men leading a crowd of rioters who broke past two lines of barricades manned by Capitol Police officers just before 1 p.m. on Jan. 6, the FBI stated in charging documents. He is shown on video picking up a metal barricade and shoving it into officers, causing at least one officer to fall onto steps behind her, the FBI stated. One rioter jumped over the barricade and attacked officers, and while they were trying to subdue him, Grant pulled him away. A third officer punched Grant, but he and others were able to move forward and overwhelm the officers, the documents show. He was identified in part by a cap he wore, with an image of North Carolina, and the caption "Drink local." The FBI obtained additional photos of Grant inside the Capitol by searching the cell phone of Gary Edwards, who was arrested in May.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building

characters.name: Darrell Neely
characters.charge: Theft of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: During efforts to identify him, the FBI interviewed three people who work with Neely at his radio station, Global Enlightenment Radio Network. Neely told coworkers that he acquired a Capitol Police jacket during the riot as a souvenir, as well as four china plates, the FBI stated in charging documents. He later discussed the riot on his YouTube channel.

blurbs.text: Theft of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Christian Matthew Manley
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly conduct in Capitol; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: Manley wore a tactical vest and carried what appeared to be a can of pepper spray during the Capitol riot, the FBI wrote in charging documents. Surveillance footage showed him spraying pepper spray at officers during the melee on the lower west terrace and then throwing the can at them, the FBI stated. At 2:55 pm. he was handed a metal rod by another rioter and threw it at the officers, the records state.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly conduct in Capitol; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building

characters.name: Julio Cesar Chang
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: A tipster told the FBI that Chang posted on Facebook that he had participated in the Jan. 6 riot, sharing photos of train tickets and comments about the "1776 Part 2 Revolution." The FBI reported seeing a post of Chang, wearing a Trump ball cap and U.S. flag scarf, outside the Capitol captioned "The deplorables have taken back our country." He was also seen on security footage inside the Capitol, the FBI stated. He is a former employee of the Broward County Sheriff's Office, and was identified by former co-workers.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Meghan Rutledge
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Rutledge entered the Capitol with her father, William Thomas Bostic Jr. and possibly another family member, the FBI stated in charging documents. The agency was alerted to her identity by tipsters who had known her. They saw her posts on Facebook and provided screenshots to the FBI. "After miles and miles of walking and climbing and climbing some more we made it inside the capitol building. What an experience for the books," one post read. The documents also state another member of the Rutledge family was with Bostic and Rutledge in the Capitol, according to security video. The FBI stated that she subsequently deleted her Facebook account.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: William Thomas Bostic Jr.
characters.title: Tom
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

image.alt: Photo of William Thomas Bostic Jr.

characters.description: Bostic and his daughter, Meghan Rutledge, went to the Capitol together, multiple people told the FBI, according to court documents. The tipsters took screenshots of Facebook posts Rutledge made that appeared to be photos taken inside the Capitol. Charging documents state that grand jury subpoenas for cell phone records showed Bostic had communications prior to Jan. 6 with a person who coordinated convoys, communications plans, maps and lists including a packing list. That list included a baton, body armor, helmets and portable chargers.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: James Phillip Mault
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description:
Mault traveled to Washington D.C. with friends on a bus driven by his father to protest the election certification. He was identified by the unique stickers on a helmet he wore, including one which identified his Ironworkers union in his hometown of Rochester, New York. When Mault was arrested in October, he'd been in the U.S. Army for six months.

The FBI stated he was seen on body worn camera video spraying chemical agents toward law enforcement officers.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty April 22, 2022 to assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers or employees.
characters.sentence: Sentenced July 15, 2022 to 44 months in prison, three years of supervised release and $2,000 restitution.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
Pleaded guilty April 22, 2022 to assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers or employees.
Sentenced July 15, 2022 to 44 months in prison, three years of supervised release and $2,000 restitution.

characters.name: Cody Mattice
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description:
Mattice was seen on video rinsing his eyes after being pepper sprayed at the Capitol, according to federal charging documents. He traveled to Washington D. C. with his friend James Mault, who was also arrested, and four friends, on a bus driven by Mault's father, the documents stated. Mattice was identified by an officer with the Brockport Police Department who had arrested him once during a traffic stop.

In D.C. Mattice was seen ripping down a barrier to allow protesters to bypass law enforcement officers, the FBI stated. He also was seen on police body camera video on a sallyport at the lower west terrace spraying a chemical agent in the direction of law enforcement officers.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty April 22, 2022 to assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers or employees.
characters.sentence: Sentenced July 15, 2022 to 44 months in prison, three years of supervised release and $2,000 restitution.

Pleaded guilty April 22, 2022 to assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers or employees.

characters.name: Isaac Westbury
characters.charge: Civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: Westbury was arrested with his father. The two men and fellow Minnesota resident Aaron James were indicted by a federal grand jury in September on charges related to the Capitol riot. His brother Jonah Westbury was charged in April.

characters.description: A trio of Minnesota men, Aaron James and father and son duo Robert and Isaac Westbury, were indicted by a federal grand jury in September on charges related to participating in the riot.

characters.name: Edward Spain Jr.
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Spain traveled to Washington D.C. from Oklahoma with friends to attend the rally, then entered the Capitol alone after hearing someone had been shot, he told the FBI in an interview and written confession. After agents contacted him, he handed over a bag of the clothes he wore to the riot and showed them a U.S. Army hat he wore. "I did not vandalize anything. I had no intent of causing harm or to anyone or anything. I utilized poor judgment in doing so," he wrote.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Jan. 28, 2022, to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced May 4, 2022 to 36 months of probation, including 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.

characters.description: Online sleuths led the FBI to the identities of Wren and his cousin Thomas Smith. The pair, dubbed #MississippiFlagGuy and #KingstonAsh by the online sleuths, were named in a 10-count October indictment.

characters.description: Online sleuths led the FBI to the identities of Smith and his cousin Donnie Wren. The pair, dubbed #MississippiFlagGuy and #KingstonAsh by the online sleuths, were named in a 10-count October indictment. The Dispatch newspaper in Columbus, Mississippi, reported that Smith is a former foreman for the Oktibbeha County road department, who was charged with a felony in March, accused of stealing gas from the road department in 2019. The newspaper reported the department fired Smith in August 2019.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building

characters.name: Cara Maureen Hentschel
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
The tale of Hentschel and Mahailya Pryer's trip to Washington D.C. and the Capitol wound up with the ending of their friendship, FBI charging documents show. The pair of women went to D.C. with two other people, one who was related to Pryer. Someone who does not know Hentschel told the FBI that she had posted photos showing she was at the Capitol on Jan. 6. Agents later found an Instagram photo selfie of her on the Capitol steps. She also posted a photo of herself with Mehailya Pryer listening to President Trump's speech. Both women were wearing stocking caps with the number "45." Federal charging documents state the FBI first tried to interview Hentschel in March, but she declined to answer questions unless charged with a crime. FBI agents stated they used a Google warrant and determined Hentschel's phone was present at the Capitol on Jan. 6, and later found both her and Pryer in surveillance footage inside the Capitol. During an attempt to interview Pryer on June 16, the FBI agent said Pryer told them she did not want to incriminate herself but that she and Hentschel were no longer friends.

In a warrant served on Facebook, the FBI stated it uncovered a message conversation where Hentschel told a friend she was with the "first group in." She went on to say: "We storm{sic) peloskis(sic) office and took her beer. She drinks Corona." The documents state the FBI was unable to see Hentschel or Pryer on surveillance footage inside Pelosi's office.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty May 18, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty May 18, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Lawrence Dropkin Jr.
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
characters.description: The first tip to the FBI about Dropkin's identity was on Jan. 7, from a witness who said Dropkin made a FaceTime call with someone while inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, the agency stated in federal charging documents. The second tip, on Jan. 22, was from a relative by marriage who reported Dropkin's father said his son was inside House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office. The FBI stated he can be seen on Capitol surveillance video for about 36 minutes, wearing a "Make America Great Again ball cap.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty July 12, 2022 to all counts.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building
Pleaded guilty July 12, 2022 to all counts.

characters.name: Michael Dickinson
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
characters.description: A tipster identified Dickinson to the FBI on Jan. 9, according to federal charging documents. Dickinson was injured, the tipster told agents, and was in a hospital in Washington D.C. In a video, Dickinson can be seen throwing an object that looked like a coffee tumbler and hitting an officer in the face, the FBI stated. According to the charging documents, Dickinson was treated in a nearby hospital for facial injuries which he said were caused by a rubber bullet.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings.

characters.name: Anthony Vuksanaj
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Vuksanaj was identified as a suspect in the Capitol riot after being arrested on an armed robbery charge. Charging documents state his cell phone number was on a list of cell numbers that were active at the Capitol on the day of the riot. An FBI agent matched his booking photo to photos of him taken inside the Capitol during the riot.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Jan. 7, 2022, to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced April 29, 2022 to three years of probation, including 42 days of intermittent confinement to be served in three 14-day increments, three months of home detention, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution.

Sentenced April 29, 2022 to three years of probation, including 42 days of intermittent confinement to be served in three 14-day increments, three months of home detention, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution.

characters.name: Mahailya Pryer
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

They wore matching "45" stocking caps to the Capitol riot, but by the time the FBI came knocking, Mahailya Pryer and Cara Hentschel were no longer friends, Pryer told the FBI. Charging documents show the women went to Washington D.C. with two other people, including one who was related to Pryer. She also posted a photo of herself with Mehailya Pryer listening to President Trump's speech. Both women were wearing stocking caps with the number "45." Federal charging documents state the FBI first tried to interview Hentschel in March, but she declined to answer questions unless charged with a crime. FBI agents stated they used a Google warrant and determined Hentschel's phone was present at the Capitol on Jan. 6, and later found both her and Pryer in surveillance footage inside the Capitol. During an attempt to interview Pryer on June 16, the FBI agent said Pryer told them she did not want to incriminate herself but that she and Hentschel were no longer friends.

In a warrant served on Facebook, the FBI stated it uncovered a message conversation in which Hentschel told a friend she was with the "first group in." She went on to say: "We storm{sic) peloskis(sic) office and took her beer. She drinks Corona." The documents state the FBI was unable to see Hentschel or Pryer on surveillance footage inside Pelosi's office.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty May 18, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Moises Romero
characters.charge: Civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading or demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: The FBI received its first tip about Romero a day after the riot, when a person he's known since high school saw his posts about being inside the Capitol on Instagram. The FBI states surveillance video shows Romero near the front of the line of rioters pushing against police officers.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty March 16, 2022 to civil disorder.
characters.sentence: Sentenced July 22, 2022 to 12 months and 1 day imprisonment, 12 months supervised release, 60 hours community service and $2,000 restitution.

blurbs.text: Civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading or demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Rafael Rondon
characters.charge: Theft of government property; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; entering and remaining in the  Gallery of Congress; entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building.
characters.description: On the same day Rondon was charged with participating in the Capitol riot with his mother, Maryann Mooney-Rondon, he was also charged with possession of an unregistered sawed-off shotgun at his residence. In an interview with the FBI, Rondon said they went to the Capitol to have their voices heard.

blurbs.text: Theft of government property; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; entering and remaining in the Gallery of Congress; entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Maryann Mooney-Rondon
characters.charge: Theft of government property; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; entering and remaining in the Gallery of Congress; entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
Mooney-Rondon and her son entered the Capitol at about 2:23 p.m. and made it up to the suite of offices for Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi in about 9 minutes, the FBI stated in charging documents. Videos show her advising someone who was picking up a laptop off the table in that office to put on gloves, and she later admitted to the FBI that she provided the gloves, the documents stated. In an interview with the FBI, she said the man who was taking the laptop scared her. By 2:42 p.m., she and her son were in the Senate Gallery overlooking the Senate floor. Theft charges stem to a video which showed them carrying emergency escape hoods with satchels that were kept in the Capitol for members of Congress and staff. Each cost about $235.

After serving a search warrant in June, the FBI found jackets the pair were wearing in the videos, as well as the escape hood bags.

blurbs.text: Theft of government property; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; entering and remaining in the Gallery of Congress; entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Jeremy Brown
characters.charge: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; knowingly and with intent to impede or disrupt the orderly conduct of government business or official functions, engage in disorderly or disruptive conduct in any restricted building or grounds.
characters.description:
Jeremy Brown, a self-identified retired green beret who ran for Congress in Florida in 2020, wore full tactical gear to the Capitol riot and told the FBI that he provided security for VIPs at the Stop the Steal rally. A tipster who had known him for years recognized him in the gear in a photo taken in Washington D.C. on Jan. 5, according to federal charging documents. In photos, he wore a helmet, radio, tactical vest, gloves and goggles, and had a large pair of surgical trauma scissors tucked into a pocket and zip ties attached to his belt The FBI stated he was seen in body camera footage as a group of police officers tried to resecure restricted Capitol grounds. Agents said he retreated only after police pushed back with batons, but he has not yet been identified in photos or videos inside the Capitol.

One of the defendants who had already reached a plea deal with federal officials provided a statement with details of Brown's involvement and planning. In December messages planning the trip, the FBI stated he referred to his RV as "GROUND FORCE ONE." In one message he wrote, "Plenty of gun ports left to fill."

On the day after the riot, Brown wrote the following message: "Everything you are watching on the Media and Houses of Congress is a lie! I was shot in the neck with pepper balls and beating in the forearm with a nightstick trying to shield unprotected Civilians from being hit in the head. This was an exercise in the unrestrained addiction to power." The FBI stated he was seen in podcasts saying he had deposited his guns with another person in Virginia before going into Washington D.C. and retrieved them after the riot.

The FBI reported that law enforcement agents called Brown on Jan. 6 and 7, but did not discuss why. In a later document, the FBI said Brown's case overlaps with the case against other members of the Oath Keepers, several of whom have been charged with conspiracy.

blurbs.text: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; knowingly and with intent to impede or disrupt the orderly conduct of government business or official functions, engage in disorderly or disruptive conduct in any restricted building or grounds.

characters.name: Brandon Prenzlin
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Prenzlin, a former grassroots organizer for the Freedom Works organization, lost his job when he was charged and arrested in September for participating in the Capitol riot, the Huffington Post reported. The FBI used social media and a pair of distinctive navy blue shoes he was wearing to track down his identity. An agent said he was wearing the same shoes at the riot that he was wearing in a Twitter post by a colleague over the summer and when he was under surveillance at Washington Reagan International Airport in June. Based on security camera footage, the FBI determined Prenzlin was inside the Capitol for 3 minutes and 35 seconds.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty March 25, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced June 28, 2022 to 10 months of probation, $2500 fine, $500 restitution and 120 hours of community service.

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty March 25, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Sentenced June 28, 2022 to 10 months of probation, $2500 fine, $500 restitution and 120 hours of community service.

characters.name: Richard Bryan Watrous
characters.charge: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
Watrous is seen on video, wearing a red Trump ball cap, entering the U.S. Capitol through the Upper House Door around 2:48 pm on Jan. 6 and remained inside about 5 minutes, the FBI stated in charging documents. Watrous told the FBI in an interview that he planned to travel from his home in New York to Washington D.C. as soon as President Trump told people to do so. Documents show he told the FBI he knew the day was significant because of the debate to certify the presidential election, but he didn't think he'd have any impact on that debate.

Watrous listened to Trump speak during the rally and then walked to the Capitol, hearing flashbangs before he was even close. He told the FBI that after he got inside, he thought "the whole vibe was uncomfortable to me because I could see something else going on. I was pissed they were allowing it to happen," according to the charging documents. He also told the agents he "wasn't sure I was supposed to be there" and that the people around him seemed like troublemakers, not peaceful protestors. After he left the Capitol the first time, he stayed on the steps for about 15 minutes and then re-entered with a woman who said she had a YouTube channel and wanted to go inside to see.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Jan. 6, 2022, to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced April 21, 2022 to 36 months of probation, including 14 days in jail, 60 days of home confinement, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution

blurbs.text: Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty Jan. 6, 2022, to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Sentenced April 21, 2022 to 36 months of probation, including 14 days in jail, 60 days of home confinement, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution

characters.name: David Ticas
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Ticas, a retired U.S. Marine Corps staff sergeant, posted a photo of himself in the crypt of the Capitol on Instagram, with the caption "Storm the Capital! #StopTheSteal #DemocratsAreCriminals." A witness, who knew Ticas through the Marine Corps, took a screenshot of that post and sent it to the FBI on Jan. 8. Through a search warrant served on Google, the FBI determined that Ticas' phone was in the Capitol on Jan. 6. The FBI also located him in surveillance footage from the Senate Wing door and the Hall of Columns. The FBI said it further identified him through surveillance in May at Los Angeles International Airport.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty April 26, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced July 15, 2022 to 14 days of incarceration, 24 months of probation, 60 hours community service and $500 restitution.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Pleaded guilty April 26, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Sentenced July 15, 2022 to 14 days of incarceration, 24 months of probation, 60 hours community service and $500 restitution.

characters.name: Mick Chan
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description:
Chan told the FBI during an interview that he “broke into, well, air quotes, broke into” the Capitol, after others had already breached the building, then walked around the Rotunda for about 15 minutes taking pictures, according to a federal charging document. He estimated that he was in the building for about 30 minutes. He told the FBI that he carried an item he called a "stab and poke" for self-defense in Washington because he was concerned people would attack Trump supporters. Someone tipped the FBI to his identity on Feb. 7, providing screen shots of social posts. The next day, Chan obtained a phone number for an FBI special agent from a friend and texted the agent. "Someone about to post on my behalf thru fb ... I'll be known publicly that I've entered Capitol. Any fallout u think I should be aware of?"

In a second interview, the FBI said Chan told the agency he stayed in Washington DC a few days after Jan. 6 and believed he suffered a concussion, and that he was considering joining a class action lawsuit for people who were teargassed on Jan. 6. Chan also told the FBI that he entered the Capitol with "journalistic intent" to get photos to share but the FBI reported it had not uncovered any evidence that he was acting as a journalist or member of the news media.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Erik Herrera
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; obstruction of Justice/Congress
characters.description: Even though Herrera wore a "press" patch to the Capitol riot, the FBI concluded that he was not a professional photojournalist after not finding any published photos or works by him. A tipster originally alerted the FBI to his identity. The agents also uncovered messages he'd sent indicating his interest in the Capitol was dissatisfaction with the electoral process in 2020. "People are fed up," he told someone in an instagram message. In another message he posted that he was in D.C. "for both photojournalism and our people."

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; obstruction of Justice/Congress

characters.name: Anthony Sargent
characters.charge: Destruction of government property, entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in any restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in any restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
characters.description: Sargent was identified by the FBI as a Proud Boy, who once dubbed himself in a Twitter account profile as an "Ancient City Proud Boy Constitutionalist unapologetic no mask." Sargent was identified in videos taken of rioters trying to break through the outer doors and the inner doors of the Capitol's north entrance, and appeared to be wearing a radio on the pocket of his jeans. The rioters caused an estimated $1,000 in damage to the north doors, the FBI stated in charging documents. Agents conducted surveillance on Sargent in St. Augustine, attempting to match him to images obtained at the Capitol.

blurbs.text: Destruction of government property, entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in any restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in any restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings

characters.name: David Wiersma
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings
characters.description: A Facebook friend and former co-worker turned Wiersma in to the FBI on Jan. 12 after seeing a post talking about how he had entered the Capitol on Jan. 6. Wiersma posted that he and a friend spent about 30 minutes inside and "got out before the swat team went in." The FBI concluded the person with him was Dawn Frankowski, who has a Facebook account with the display name "Dawn Maga."

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings

characters.name: Dawn Frankowski
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings
characters.description: Frankowski was seen at the Capitol on Jan. 6 with David Wiersma, who posted about being at the Capitol rally on Facebook. A friend and colleague turned Wiersma in. Frankowski admitted to the FBI that she was at the Capitol.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings

characters.name: Matthew Joseph Buckler
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct at any place in the grounds or in any of the Capitol buildings; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings
characters.description: Buckler is seen in a video from his own phone inside the Capitol, chanting "Stop the Steal" repeatedly, federal officials stated in charging documents. Although Buckler was wearing a hoodie and a Trump cap, the records contain no other information about his interests outside the Capitol that day.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty May 27, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Captiol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced July 21, 2022 to 14 days of home detention, 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service and $500 restitution.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct at any place in the grounds or in any of the Capitol buildings; parade, demonstrate or picket in any of the Capitol buildings
Pleaded guilty May 27, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Captiol building.
Sentenced July 21, 2022 to 14 days of home detention, 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service and $500 restitution.

characters.name: Michael Eckerman
characters.charge: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; disorderly conduct in the Capitol building; entering and remaining in a restricted building; entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds.
characters.description: Eckerman pushed his way to the front of a crowd and shoved an officer back several feet, causing the officer to fall down a small set of stairs, the Department of Justice stated in a news release about his arrest. The incident allowed rioters to move farther into the Capitol, and Eckerman made it to Statuary Hall where he pushed through another set of officers and yelled for several minutes. Eckerman was captured on police body camera video yelling at officers. He was accompanied by two companions, who went with him into the Rayburn reception room inside the House of Representatives, the FBI stated. Tipsters revealed his identity to the FBI. Inside the Capitol, Eckerman posed for a photo, wearing a tactical vest, Trump hat and a neon glove in front of a large painting of George Washington.

blurbs.text: Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; disorderly conduct in the Capitol building; entering and remaining in a restricted building; entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds.

characters.name: Charles Bradford Smith
characters.title: Brad Smith
characters.charge: Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; Impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; Unlawful possession of a dangerous weapon on Capitol grounds or buildings; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds; Impeding passage through the capitol grounds or buildings and aiding and abetting
characters.description:
Smith and his friend Marshall Neefe discussed ahead of time their plans to attend the Jan. 6 rally in Washington D.C., federal officials said in announcing their arrests. The pair discussed taking batons, and Smith told someone on Facebook that he had purchased a military knife to take with him. On Jan. 5, on another Facebook post, he commented: "Sacrifice the Senate!!!!!," the news release stated.

In Facebook messages, Smith said: "We literally chased them into hiding. No certification lol."

blurbs.text: Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; Impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; Unlawful possession of a dangerous weapon on Capitol grounds or buildings; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds; Impeding passage through the capitol grounds or buildings and aiding and abetting

characters.name: Tara Aileen Stottlemyer
characters.charge: Obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Stottlemyer was named in an indictment with Dale Jeremiah Shalvey, who is her boyfriend according to The Times Leader, a newspaper in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. The couple was featured in a December story in the Observer-Reporter newspaper in Pennsylvania. The story stated the couple raised turkeys and other poultry, which they sell through an online business called Redemption Farms, and practice regenerative agriculture.

blurbs.text: Obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Marshall Neefe
characters.charge: Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; Civil disorder; Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; Disorderly conduct in a capitol building or grounds; Act of physical violence in the capitol building or grounds; Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a capitol building
characters.description:
Neefe communicated with Brad Smith, also of Pennsylvania, in the days leading up to the rally and riot in Washington D.C. Records provided by the FBI and the U.S. Department of Justice show their communications, a news release stated. The day after the election, Neefe wrote to Smith: "I'm getting ready to storm D.C." In one of the notes, he stated: “We goin? ...Cause hot damn son I really wanna crack some commie skulls.”

Neefe carried a wooden club at the Capitol and participated in hoisting and pushing a large metal sign frame into a line of police officers, the charging documents stated. In a Facebook message after the riot, he stated: "If i(sic) had my way every cop who hurled a baton or maced on(sic) of us would be lined up and put down."
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty May 3, 2022 to conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding.

blurbs.text: Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; Civil disorder; Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; Disorderly conduct in a capitol building or grounds; Act of physical violence in the capitol building or grounds; Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a capitol building
Pleaded guilty May 3, 2022 to conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding.

characters.name: Thomas Fassell
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Fassell, a disabled Air Force veteran and former postal worker, according to the Tampa Bay Times, drove with his wife Marilyn from Florida to participate in the rally in Washington D.C. to support President Trump. A relative of one of his co-workers tipped the FBI to the Fassell's identities after he showed videos of himself and his wife inside the Capitol
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty July 19, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Marilyn Fassell
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building parading; demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Fassell and her husband Thomas Fassell turned themselves in to federal authorities in Florida, after being interviewed by the FBI, which found videos taken inside the Capitol on her husband's phone. Fassell frequently posts on Facebook in support of President Trump, and a variety of conspiracy theories. In one video on the phone, the FBI reported that she said "We busted in the Capitol" and in another: "This is my house, we pay taxes for this." Court documents state she posed for a selfie-style photo in the Capitol, smoking a cigarette.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty July 19, 2022 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

blurbs.text: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building parading; demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.

characters.name: Gary Wilson
characters.charge: Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; Entering and remaining in the Gallery of Congress.
characters.description: An FBI agent wrote in an affidavit that Gary Wilson traveled from Salt Lake City to Washington, D.C. on Jan. 4. On the day of the attack, he wore an Infowars t-shirt that read, “Give me Liberty” with an image of a Revolutionary War soldier holding an assault-style weapon. He entered the Capitol through the Upper West Terrace door with two others. At one point he told an officer: “We came all the way from our jobs to do your job and the freaking senators’ job.” A family member who has known Wilson for many years helped the FBI identify him in surveillance photos.

blurbs.text: Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; Entering and remaining in the Gallery of Congress.

characters.name: Jean Lavin
characters.charge: Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.description: Lavin went with her daughter Carla Krzywicki to the Capitol riot, the FBI stated in charging documents. They posed outside of the Capitol and posted a photo on Facebook with the caption: "this is history. we do not go burning down your city and stealing from your business. we come for the government officials that are ruining our country. we go straight to the source. change needs to happen. that is our house and you work for us." The FBI found video of the women climbing a bike rack to get into the Capitol. Inside the building, Lavine carried a sign that stated: "Trump won," adorned with two U.S. flags. On the opposite side, the sign said: "Don't allow 7 states of cheaters to hijack our election!" Both women wore hats that said "Trump." Krzywicki told the FBI that she and her mother were in the Capitol for about 30 minutes, left for 20 minutes and then went back inside for 20 minutes. After her mother fell, Krzywicki said they left the building.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Jan. 11, 2022, to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced April 22, 2022 to 36 months of probation, including 10 days of intermittent incarceration, 60 days of home detention, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution.

characters.description: Krzywicki went with her mother, Jean Lavin, to the Capitol riot, the FBI stated in charging documents. The FBI found video of the women climbing a bike rack to get into the Capitol. Inside the building, Lavin carried a sign that stated: "Trump won," adorned with two U.S. flags. On the opposite side, the sign said: "Don't allow 7 states of cheaters to hijack our election!" Both women wore hats that said "Trump." After her mother fell, Krzywicki said they left the building.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Dec. 23, 2021, to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced April 22, 2022 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days of home detention, $500 restitution.
