characters.name: Grant Moore
characters.charge: Carrying a pistol without a license and unregistered ammunition
characters.description:
Capitol Police found Moore parked in his white Ford Econoline 150 van near the Capitol, and Moore admitted to having a gun in his backpack on the front passenger seat.

Officers found a Ruger pistol in a holster, according to D.C. Superior Court records. The gun was loaded with six rounds, and officers recovered three more six-round magazines along with 12 loose rounds.

blurbs.text: Carrying a pistol without a license and unregistered ammunition

characters.name:
Joshua Pruitt, 39, was arrested twice by Metro Police for violating the Riot Act, unlawful entry and curfew violations. Then the Justice Department charged him with additional charges, after a federal grand jury indicted him. When Pruitt filed a guilty plea in June 2022, additional information emerged about his time in the Capitol. Pruitt marched with the Maryland Proud Boys on Jan. 6 and wore a tactical glove with knuckle pads. He used a piece of makeshift fencing as a ladder to climb onto the Capitol stairs and arrived in the Crypt at approximately 2:14 p.m. according to a statement of offense he signed.
As the crowd overwhelmed the police line there, he followed officers down a staircase to the Capitol visitors center where he threw a chair in the direction the officers had retreated and walked toward the Senate subway. At that point he encountered Senate Minority leader Charles Schumer and his security detail, who were attempting to reach their motorcade to move Schumer to a secure location. As they were waiting by the elevators, a member of the security detail saw Pruitt and another man approaching. Schumer and his security detail reversed course and ran away from the elevator. 
Pruitt turned around and was involved in another altercation with officers at the visitor center. He later messaged someone saying: "inside was fun." In a CNN interview after the riot, he said he was a patriot protesting "a stolen election."

characters.name: Lonnie Leroy Coffman
characters.charge: Possession of an unregistered firearm (destructive device) and carrying a pistol without a license.
characters.description: When authorities found Coffman's truck near the Capitol, they reported finding 11 Molotov cocktails -- Mason jars filled with flammable liquids -- in addition to guns and ammunition.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Nov. 12 to one count of possession of an unregistered firearm and carrying a pistol without a license.
characters.sentence: Sentenced April 1, 2022 to 46 months in prison, followed by three years of supervised release.

characters.charge: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; assault on a federal law enforcement officer; and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
characters.description: Leffingwell is accused of entering the Senate side of the Capitol. When police stopped him, the complaint says, he struck an officer in the helmet and chest.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Oct. 26 to assaulting resisting or impeding a federal officer.

characters.charge: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
characters.description: Authorities accuse Council of unlawfully entering the Capitol building. When police stopped him, the complaint says, he pushed an officer.

characters.name: Michael Curzio
characters.charge: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; or knowingly, with intent to impede government business or official functions, engaging in disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
characters.description:
Michael Curzio was among the rioters arrested by U.S. Capitol Police for unlawful entry. It was not the Florida man’s first brush with law enforcement.

Curzio, 35, was released from prison in February 2019 following an eight-year sentence for attempted first-degree murder, according to records from the Florida Department of Corrections.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty July 12 to parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
characters.sentence: Sentenced 7/12 to six months incarceration and $500 in restitution.

characters.name: Hunter A. Ehmke
characters.charge: Damaging or destroying government property; obstruction of an official proceeding; Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
characters.description: An officer outside the Capitol rotunda door observed Ehmke strike and break a window while standing on a ledge as a mob of people approached, according to court records. Using his shield, the officer knocked Ehmke off the ledge and other officers handcuffed him. They took his name, photo and driver's license but were overwhelmed by the throng of people, including one who said, “You’re not leaving with him." The officers released Ehmke but kept his license. He was charged Jan. 11.
characters.case_outcome: Pleaded guilty Jan. 14, 2022, to destruction of government property.
characters.sentence: Sentenced May 13, 2022 to four months in prison, 36 months of supervised release and $2,821 in restitution.
